assignments.name: Lab Assignment: Unit 0.3 [Final Submission] [New Students]
assignments.description:
Collaboration Policy

The collaboration category for this assignment is Category C: Group Assignment with Limited External Collaboration. Refer to the Student Conduct section in the syllabus for more information. 

 

Assignment Materials

Lab Assignment

Unit 0.3 - Lab Instructions.pdf

 

Activity: Peer Review of Lab Notebooks

Composition 1

Composition 2

Composition 3

PDF Versions (Stored on Canvas)

Composition 1.pdf

Composition 2.pdf

Composition 3.pdf

Videos

These videos are featured in the assignment. 

Composition 1 - Video of Experimental Setup

Assignment Instructions

 

 

1. Prepare for your lab session

Before your lab session begins, do the following:

1.1 Review the Assignment

Review the lab assignment on your own or with your group. This pre-session review will allow your group to use your lab session time more efficiently and ensure that your group passes the lab check-in.

1.2 Grading Rubrics

Review the grading rubric at the bottom of this assignment. This rubric establishes performance expectations for student work and discloses how your instructor will grade your work.

1.3 Time Management 

Each activity in the lab assignment specifics how much time your group should spend on it. Review these times.

To complete all activities by the end of the lab session, your group should employ best practices for group work, such as parallel processing and setting deadlines. Develop a plan for dividing up the work for each activity among your group members. 

If your group is struggling to manage their time, ask your lab instructor for advice during the lab check-ins.

1.4 Canvas Groups

At the beginning of each lab session, verify that your Canvas Group for the session is consistent with your group-member assignment by navigating to People, clicking the Groups tab, and selecting the appropriate Group Set. 

If you need to modify your group for any reason (e.g., your Canvas group assignment is wrong, a group member is missing, etc.), follow these instructions. Use only the existing groups that are listed for your section; do not create a new group.

 

2. Complete the assignment

Work with your group to complete the activities from the lab assignment for this session. Your group needs to document and record all their work for this unit in their lab notebook.

 

3. Upload your work to Canvas

When you have completed your work on the assignment, do the following:

 

3.1 Prepare your work for submission

Convert your lab notes into a single PDF. 

 

3.2 Submit your work

Upload the PDF of your lab notebook and click Submit Assignment.

If you make multiple submissions, your instructor will grade your most recent submission.

 

3.3 Verify that your submission uploaded properly.

After submitting your work, you must verify that you have correctly and successfully uploaded your work by following these steps:

  1. Download your submission from Canvas and open the downloaded files on a device with a PDF viewer, such as Adobe Reader and Preview (Mac). Viewing your submission in Canvas's previewer or the Canvas app is not sufficient since caching issues can obscure errors in a file. To download your submission, follow these steps:
    • For previewable files, click the download button in the upper left corner of Canvas's previewer.

    • For non-previewable files, click the download button at the bottom of the "Preview Unavailable" message.

  2. Verify the file is operable, meaning that it is not corrupted. 
  3. Verify the file contains all your work.
  4. Finally, confirm you have uploaded your work to the correct assignment.

The most common submission error is upload failure. When a student uploads work for an assignment, Canvas will display a confirmation message such as "Submitted!" and may show a confetti animation on the screen. However, based on past experience, these notifications are unreliable. The only way to guarantee that you have successfully uploaded your work to Canvas is to download your submission from Canvas. 

Because of the grace period and students' responsibility to verify their submissions, submission errors are not considered extenuating circumstances.  So, please do yourself a favor and take a minute to verify your submission. 

 

3.4 Resolve submission errors.

If you experience any submission errors, try

  1. uploading your work through Google Drive,
  2. using a different browser,
  3. using a browser in private browsing mode, such as Chrome's Incognito Mode,
  4. traveling to campus and using the university's internet or 
  5. traveling to campus and using a public computer in the library.

 

 

3.5 Final Submission

This is the final submission for this unit. Your instructor will grade your final submission using the assignment's rubric.

2. Document your work in your lab notebook

Work with your group to complete the activities from the lab assignment for this session. Your group needs to document and record all their work for this unit in their digital lab notebook.

 

2.1 Composition

Your group should compose their notes according to the Lab Notebook Composition Guidelines.

At the end of the session, convert your lab notes for this unit into a single PDF.

2.2 Phone use

You are encouraged to use your phone to document your experiments, such as taking pictures of your experimental setup or any relevant drawings or sketches and including these pictures in your lab notebook. With that said, during the lab sessions, you are only allowed to use your phone for lab-related reasons. As such, you should turn off any notifications to help you stay focused on your group's experiment during the lab session. 

 

3. Upload your work to Canvas

When you have completed your work on the assignment, do the following:

 

3.1 Submit your lab notes

Below, upload your group's lab notes as a single PDF, and then click Submit Assignment.

This is a group assignment. All members of a group can upload documents for a group assignment. If a group makes multiple submissions for an assignment, the group can only see their most recent submission. Your instructor will grade your group's most recent submission.

 

3.2 Verify that your submission uploaded properly.

After submitting your work, you must verify that you have correctly and successfully uploaded your work by following these steps:

  1. Download your submission from Canvas and open the downloaded files on a device with a PDF viewer, such as Adobe Reader and Preview (Mac).     • For previewable files, click the download button in the upper left corner of Canvas's previewer.

    • For non-previewable files, click the download button at the bottom of the "Preview Unavailable" message.

  2. Verify the file is operable, meaning that it is not corrupted. 
  3. Verify the file contains all your work.
  4. Finally, confirm you have uploaded your work to the correct assignment.

The most common submission error is upload failure. When a student uploads work for an assignment, Canvas will display a confirmation message such as "Submitted!" and may show a confetti animation on the screen. However, based on past experience, these notifications are unreliable. The only way to guarantee that you have successfully uploaded your work to Canvas is to download your submission from Canvas. 

Because of the grace period and students' responsibility to verify their submissions, submission errors are not considered extenuating circumstances.  So, please do yourself a favor and take a minute to verify your submission. 

 

3.3 Resolve submission errors.

If you experience any submission errors, try

  1. uploading your work through Google Drive,
  2. using a different browser,
  3. using a browser in private browsing mode, such as Chrome's Incognito Mode,
  4. traveling to campus and using the university's internet or 
  5. traveling to campus and using a public computer in the library.

 

 

3.4 Preliminary Submission

This is a preliminary submission of your group's lab notes for the unit. Your instructor will use the assignment's rubric to evaluate the current state of your group's lab notes, which will provide your group with feedback about what they did well and how they can improve their notes before their final submission.

Preliminary submissions are graded on a Complete/Incomplete basis. If your group submits preliminary lab notes, your group will receive a Complete (i.e., full points). If not, your group will receive an Incomplete (i.e., no points).

assignments.name: Homework 0.3: Mathematica Tutorial - Problem Exercises [New Students]
assignments.description:
Collaboration Policy

The collaboration category for this assignment is Category B: Individual Assignment with Limited Collaboration. Refer to the Student Conduct section in the syllabus for more information. 

 

Description

Mathematica is computational software that's used in many scientific and engineering fields. Since computational software is a fundamental tool in modern science, and we want this course to provide students with an authentic experience of how science is done, we decided students should use Mathematica in this course. Many of the homework assignments will be Mathematica-based, and you will use it in the lab sessions to record and analyze your data. Therefore, to be successful in this course, you will need to become proficient in using Mathematica. To help you gain that proficiency, we have designed a series of self-paced tutorials and in-class activities that teach students how to operate Mathematica and bypass mistakes that first-time users often make.

In this tutorial, you will learn the basic structure of Mathematica, the programming language that Mathematica understands, and how to write code to perform various computational tasks.

 

 

Estimated Time

2-3 hours

Assignment Materials

Files

Homework 0.3 - Mathematica Tutorial - Problem Set.nb

 

Solutions

Homework 0.3 - Mathematica Tutorial - Practice [Solutions].nb

Homework 0.3 - Mathematica Tutorial - Problem Set [Solutions].nb

(You will be able to access these solutions after the deadline for this assignment.)

 

 

Videos

These videos are featured in the tutorial. 
(The Canvas video player defaults to the lowest quality setting. You can increase the quality manually by clicking on the gear icon  in the video's control panel.)

Creating an Input Cell

Copying and Pasting a Cell

Cell Groups

  • In Mathematica, navigate to the Menu Bar, select File>Save As..., and under Save as type, select PDF Document (*.pdf).

 

3.1 Submit your work

Below, upload two files:

  1. the Mathematica notebook (.nb ) containing your work and
  2. the PDF of that notebook.

Then, click Submit Assignment.

If you make multiple submissions, your instructor will grade your most recent submission.

  2. Verify the file is operable, meaning that it is not corrupted.

Homework 1.2: Uncertainty Tutorial [New Students]
assignments.description:
Collaboration Policy

The collaboration category for this assignment is Category B: Individual Assignment with Limited Collaboration. Refer to the Student Conduct section in the syllabus for more information. 

 

Description

All measurements have some inherent uncertainty. This tutorial is designed to help you understand measurement uncertainty and how to quantify it.

 

Estimated Time

2-3 hours

 

Assignment Materials

Download the following files. Open the file named Homework 1.2 - Uncertainty Tutorial.nb to begin the tutorial.

Files

Homework 1.2 - Uncertainty Tutorial.nb

Assignment Instructions

 

1. Review the Grading Rubric

Review the grading rubric at the bottom of this assignment. This rubric establishes performance expectations for student work and discloses how your instructor will grade your work. 

 

2. Complete the tutorial

Complete all exercises labeled Questions. There are 19 questions. 

Ensure you routinely save your work as you progress through the tutorial.

 

 

3. Upload your work to Canvas

When you have completed your work on the assignment, do the following:

3.1 Prepare your work for submission

Convert your Mathematica notebook into a single PDF.  

  • In Mathematica, navigate to the Menu Bar, select File>Save As..., and under Save as type, select PDF Document (*.pdf).

 

3.1 Submit your work

Below, upload two files:

  1. the Mathematica notebook (.nb ) containing your work and
  2. the PDF of that notebook.

Then, click Submit Assignment.

If you make multiple submissions, your instructor will grade your most recent submission.

 

 

3.2 Verify that your submission uploaded properly.

After submitting your work, you must verify that you have correctly and successfully uploaded your work by following these steps:

  1. Download your submission from Canvas and open the downloaded files on a device with a PDF viewer, such as Adobe Reader and Preview (Mac). Viewing your submission in Canvas's previewer or the Canvas app is not sufficient since caching issues can obscure errors in a file. To download your submission, follow these steps:
    • For previewable files, click the download button in the upper left corner of Canvas's previewer.

    • For non-previewable files, click the download button at the bottom of the "Preview Unavailable" message.

  2. Verify the file is operable, meaning that it is not corrupted. 
  3. Verify the file contains all your work.
  4. Finally, confirm you have uploaded your work to the correct assignment.

The most common submission error is upload failure. When a student uploads work for an assignment, Canvas will display a confirmation message such as "Submitted!" and may show a confetti animation on the screen. However, based on past experience, these notifications are unreliable. The only way to guarantee that you have successfully uploaded your work to Canvas is to download your submission from Canvas. 

Because of the grace period and students' responsibility to verify their submissions, submission errors are not considered extenuating circumstances.  So, please do yourself a favor and take a minute to verify your submission. 

 

3.3 Resolve submission errors.

If you experience any submission errors, try

  1. uploading your work through Google Drive,
  2. using a different browser,
  3. using a browser in private browsing mode, such as Chrome's Incognito Mode,
  4. traveling to campus and using the university's internet or 
  5. traveling to campus and using a public computer in the library.

courses.syllabus:
Contents

  1. Course Materials

  2. Course Description

  3. Course Components

  4. Submissions and Deadlines

  5. Academic Support for Students

  6. Policies about Email Communication

    1. Person of Contact

    2. Contact Information

  7. Grades and Grading Policies

  8. Deadline Extensions

  9. Making Up Missed Lab Sessions

  10. Disability Accommodations

  11. Academic Integrity and Collaboration Rules

  12. Summary: Student Responsibilities

Course Materials

Required Equipment for Lab Sessions

  1. [Mandatory] A laptop that complies with the university's computer requirements.
  2. [Optional] A set of headphones with a 3.5 mm (audio) jack.  If you have difficulty hearing the in-class discussion over the lab's audio system, you can plug your headphones into the base of the microphone unit at your station. 

 

(The University Bookstore may list a lab manual for this lab course. Do not purchase this lab manual. You will not need it for this course.)

Resolving Laptop Issues

If your laptop breaks or becomes otherwise inoperable during the semester, you can check out a loaner laptop from either VT's Software Assistance Triage's Loaner program or the University Library's Studios Technology Lending Desk. You can also use the computers in the lab room during the lab instructors' office hours.  

 

Wolfram Mathematica

Wolfram (also known as Mathematica) is a computational software program that you will use to analyze data and visualize statistics in this course. Mathematica is free for Virginia Tech students. Before the first unit, you will need to install Wolfram Mathematica 14.3.0 on your computer: 

  • During the installation process, ensure you choose the Wolfram + Documentation option (the larger package) to install the Wolfram Documentation Center on your computer.

 

Course Description

 

 

Course Learning Objectives

This lab course is an introduction to experimental physics and teaches students how to think critically through experimentation. By the end of this course, you should be able to:

  1. Collect data and revise an experimental procedure iteratively and reflectively,
  2. Evaluate the process and outcomes of an experiment quantitatively and qualitatively,
  3. Extend the scope of an investigation, whether or not results come out as expected,
  4. Communicate the process and outcomes of an experiment, and
  5. Conduct an experiment collaboratively and ethically.

 

Each lab unit will focus on developing and applying tools of experimental physics to extend your understanding of physics principles. Experiments in this course will often critically assess

  • the conceptual and experimental bases for the physical models discussed in the lecture and
  • the applicability or limitations of those models in specific physical situations.

 

The purpose of this lab course is not simply to reinforce concepts from lectures but rather to teach skills and tools used in experimental investigations to assess how well those concepts may model the physical world. Although our lab activities may draw upon concepts and principles from Physics 2306, you should not expect a close connection to the lectures.


Fundamentally, the goal of this course is to understand how we know, not what we know.

 

You can find a detailed enumeration of the learning objectives of this course on the Course Learning Objectives - Comprehensive page. 

 

Course Structure

In this course, you will complete a sequence of lab units. For a typical lab unit, you will attend two lab sessions, during which you will design and conduct experiments with a group of students according to the unit's instructions and grading rubric. In many cases, these instructions and rubrics are rather general, giving you the creative freedom and agency to devise your own specific procedures. Your group will document all their decisions, experiments, data, and analysis in a digital lab notebook. 

The lab sessions are presided over by a lab instructor. During the lab session, the lab instructor will periodically check in with your group, and they will provide suggestions and feedback about your group's experiments. Furthermore, your instructor will assess your group's productivity, justifications, responsiveness, empirical scrutiny, and overall teamwork. These check-ins ensure that your group stays on task, critically thinks through their experiments, works efficiently by parallel processing and that all group members are participating.

Each lab unit has homework assignments that you will complete outside of the lab session. These assignments are designed either to prepare you for an upcoming lab session or reinforce concepts from previous assignments. 

 

The structure of a typical lab unit is as follows:

Lab Session 1

Before
  • Read the instructions for the unit's first lab session.
  • Complete and submit a homework assignment related to the first session.

During
  • Familiarize yourself with the equipment and the physical system of the lab unit
  • Design and conduct an experimental investigation that evaluates a specific research question.
  • Complete specific lab activities.
  • Formally check in with your lab instructor.  

After
  • Submit a preliminary version of your group's lab notes for the unit.

Lab Session 2

Before
  • Read the instructions for the unit's second lab session.
  • Read your instructor's feedback on your preliminary submission.
  • Complete and submit a homework assignment related to the second session.

During:
  • Conduct a more open investigation that extends your investigation from the first session.
  • Formally check in with your lab instructor.  

After:
  • Submit the final version of your group's lab notes for the unit.

 

 

 

Course Organization

 

I, the Lab Director, use Canvas Modules to organize the Canvas site for this course. For each lab unit, I will provide a module that contains all the content related to that unit, such as the lab assignment, homework assignments, and submission instructions for lab notes.

 

 

Course Components

As mentioned previously, you will complete a sequence of lab units in the course. Each lab unit has the following components:

  • Lab Sessions
  • Lab Check-ins
  • a Lab Assignment
  • Homework Assignments

 

 The following sections provide detailed information about this lab course's components.

Lab Sessions

 

Format

Lab sessions last for 110 minutes and are presided over by a lab instructor. The time and location of your lab session, along with your instructor's name, are on the Lab Sessions: Times and Locations (by CRN) page.

During these sessions, you will work in an assigned group to complete specific activities outlined in the lab assignment, such as designing and conducting experiments, analyzing data, and drawing experimental inferences.  Your instructor will periodically check in with your group to offer help, provide suggestions, and assess your group's overall process and teamwork during a formal lab check-in.

You will spend most of your time in a lab session collaborating with your group members to complete the lab assignment. With that said, you are encouraged to collaborate with classmates from different groups if needed. For instance, if your group needs help but the instructor is occupied with another group, feel free to ask nearby classmates for assistance. Conversely, if another group asks for help, please consider sending over one of your group members to assist. 

We expect you to use the entire lab session to work on a lab assignment. Unless you receive permission from your instructor, you should not leave the lab session before the lab session has ended. 

 

Attendance

Attendance of the lab sessions is mandatory. If you do not attend a lab session, then you cannot receive credit for that session's lab assignment. 

You need to arrive at your lab sessions on time. If you are more than 10 minutes late for a lab session, then your instructor will ask you to leave, and you cannot receive credit for that lab's assignment unless you are given permission to perform a make-up assignment.

 

Semester Schedule of Lab Sessions 

The semester schedule for the lab sessions is posted on the Lab Sessions: Semester Schedule & Topics page. This schedule indicates when you need to attend lab sessions and the topic of each session. 

 

Lab Room

Lab sessions take place in the Undergraduate Science Lab Building* (USLB), room 346, which has 12 tables. The computer monitors on each table are labeled with the table number.

*USLB is at the corner of West Campus Dr. and Perry St. Alternatively, it's on West Campus Dr. opposite the VT Inn/Alumni Center. 

Group Member Assignments

During the lab sessions, you will be assigned to work with a group of students. These assignments are called group-member assignments.

Group-member assignments are on the Group-Member Assignment page. This page indicates who your group members are for each unit. 

I will create Canvas Groups according to these assignments. These Canvas Groups will allow your group to submit work for group assignments.


At the beginning of each lab session, verify that your Canvas Group is correct by navigating to People and clicking the Groups tab.  If you need to modify your Canvas Group (e.g., you have been reassigned to another group), follow these instructions. Use only the existing groups that are listed for your section; do not create a new group.

It is your responsibility to ensure that you are in the correct Canvas Group for each problem set. Unless you are absent, your instructor will not modify your Canvas Group. 

 

Warning: Canvas Groups Modifications after Submissions

If a student changes their Canvas Group after they have submitted their work for a group assignment, Canvas may lose the student's submission. The student who submitted the work for the assignment would still be able to access their submission, but Canvas would no longer associate their submission with the group assignment. Furthermore, there is no way for the lab instructor or the Lab Director to recover a submission after it is lost. 

Students are responsible for preventing this issue from happening. If a group experiences this issue, then, unfortunately, the group will receive a zero for the assignment since their submission is lost. 

 

Lost and Found

If a student leaves behind a personal item in the lab room, their instructor will place it in the room's Lost and Found dropbox. 

If you believe that you left behind a personal item, contact the lab manager, Henry Hilgendorf<hhilgendorf@vt.edu>, to gain access to the contents in the Lost and Found dropbox.

Lab Check-in

We expect all groups to remain productive and work purposefully during their lab sessions, and all group members to contribute equally to their group's experiment. As such, your instructor will formally check in with your group at least once during each session to assess your group's productivity, justifications, responsiveness, empirical scrutiny, and teamwork. Your instructor will grade your group on these criteria using Lab Check-in Rubrics, which will be posted under the module for the unit. 

Lab Check-ins are group assignments. All members who were present during a group check-in will receive the same grade. Students do not need to submit anything for lab check-ins.

 

 

Lab Assignments

Each lab unit has lab assignments that your group will complete during the lab sessions. The lab assignment for each unit is posted under the unit's module.

Before the lab sessions, review the unit's lab assignment on your own or with your group. This pre-session review will allow your group to use your lab session time more efficiently and ensure that your group passes the lab check-in. This includes reviewing the grading rubric for the assignment. These rubrics establish performance expectations for student work and disclose how your instructor will grade your work. Rubrics are located below the assignment instructions.

During the lab sessions, work with your group to complete the activities of the lab assignment. To do this efficiently, divide the work among your group members. For instance, while one member performs measurements, another member could prepare a Mathematica notebook to do statistical analysis. In the meantime, the third group member could prototype an improved experimental setup.

I designed the lab assignments so that groups could start and finish them within the lab session. (You will notice that the deadlines for the lab assignments are at least a couple of days after the lab session. Students do not need this additional time outside of the lab session to complete the assignment. Still, some students want additional time to compose and compile their work outside of the lab sessions. Therefore, I gave students additional time outside of the lab sessions to work on their lab assignments.)

Lab Assignments are group assignments.  All members who contribute to the group's work on the assignment (e.g., experiments, lab notes, etc.) will receive the same grade for that assignment.  

 

Lab Notebook & Composition

Your group will document and record all their work for the assignment in a digital lab notebook. Your group should include all their decisions, justifications, experimental designs, data, and analyses in the notebook. Moreover, your group should compose their notes according to the Lab Notebook Composition Guidelines.

 

Homework Assignments

Each lab unit has homework assignments that you will complete outside of the lab sessions. These assignments are designed either to prepare you for an upcoming lab session or reinforce concepts from previous assignments. 

Homework assignments include

  • guided tutorials about statistical methods, in which you investigate statistical concepts using simulations and invent mathematical descriptions (i.e., equations) to characterize patterns or trends in sample data, and
  • guided tutorials about data analysis techniques that you will use in the lab sessions,
  • reading assignments that reinforce what you learned in the guided tutorials, and
  • reading assignments about ethical issues and dilemmas in scientific research and how to mitigate bias in your experiments.

 

Homework assignments are individual assignments. 

 

Submissions and Deadlines

Every assignment contains instructions for how students should submit their work for grading. The following are submission instructions for most assignments in this course. 

Preparing your work for submission

For any assignment in this course, you must submit your work online through Canvas unless you are instructed otherwise.

Ensure your work is sufficiently resolved and legible. If your work is not legible, then your instructor cannot grade it.

 

 

Submitting your work for assignments

To submit work for an assignment, open the Canvas assignment, upload your work, and click Submit Assignment at the bottom of the assignment. 

You are allowed an unlimited number of submissions before an assignment's deadline. If you make multiple submissions, your instructor will only grade your most recent submission.

 

 

Verifying your submission

After submitting your work, you must verify that you have correctly and successfully uploaded your work by following these steps:

  1. Download your submission from Canvas and open the downloaded files with an appropriate app: a PDF viewer, such as Adobe Reader and Preview (Mac). or Mathematica. Viewing your submission in Canvas's previewer or the Canvas app is not sufficient since caching issues can obscure errors in a file. To download your submission, follow these steps:
    • For previewable files, click the download button in the upper left corner of Canvas's previewer.

    • For non-previewable files, click the download button at the bottom of the "Preview Unavailable" message.

  2. Verify the file is operable, meaning that it is not corrupted. 
  3. Verify the file contains all your work.
  4. Finally, confirm you have uploaded your work to the correct assignment.

The most common submission error is upload failure. When a student uploads work for an assignment, Canvas will display a confirmation message such as "Submitted!" and may show a confetti animation on the screen. However, based on past experience, these notifications are unreliable. The only way to guarantee that you have successfully uploaded your work to Canvas is to download your submission from Canvas. 

Because of the grace period and students' responsibility to verify their submissions, submission errors are not considered extenuating circumstances.  So, please do yourself a favor and take a minute to verify your submission. 

 

Preliminary and Final Submissions

Lab Assignments

For most units in this course, groups will work on the unit's lab assignment over two lab sessions.

Here's how the submission process works for lab assignments that span multiple sessions:

  1. After the first session, your group will upload a preliminary version of their lab notes for the assignment. 
  2. Your instructor will use the assignment's rubric to evaluate the preliminary lab notes, which will provide your group with feedback about what they did well and how they can improve their notes before the final submission.
  3. Preliminary submissions are graded on a Complete/Incomplete basis. If your group submits preliminary lab notes, your group will receive a Complete (i.e., full points). If not, your group will receive an Incomplete (i.e., no points). 
  4. Before (or during) the second session, you should read your instructors feedback on your groups preliminary submission and revise your lab notes accordingly.
  5. After the second session, your group will upload the final version of their lab notes. 
  6. Your instructor will grade the final version of your lab notes using the assignment's rubric.

 

Homework Assignments - Mathematica-based

Here's how the submission process works for Mathematica-based homework assignments for this term:

  1. You will upload a preliminary version of your work for the assignment before the preliminary due date. 
  2. The assignment will close, and within a week, your instructor will use the assignment's rubric to evaluate and grade the current state of your work, which will provide you with feedback about what you did well and how you can improve your work before the final submission.
  3. You should read your instructors feedback on your preliminary submission and revise your work accordingly.
  4. The assignment will reopen, and you will then upload your revised work for the final submission. 
    (If you do not upload work for the final submission, whatever grade you received on the preliminary submission will be your grade for the final submission.)
  5. Your instructor will grade your revised work using the assignment's rubric.

Deadlines

Deadlines for assignments are redundantly posted in multiple locations on Canvas. Deadlines are posted on

  1. the Recent Activity Feed on your Dashboard,
  2. the To-Do List on the right sidebar,
  3. the Calendar,
  4. the Upcoming Assignments list under the Assignments menu, or
  5. the Assignments list under the Grades menu. 

The following tutorial discusses each of these methods in more detail:

Keeping Track of Assignments

Students are responsible for ascertaining when their assignments are due, which is reasonable given the number of ways that Canvas communicates assignment deadlines to students.

 

Submissions for homework assignments are typically due at 11:59 PM on Thursdays before the lab session for that assignment.

Submissions for lab assignments are typically due at 11:59 PM on Thursdays after the lab session for that assignment.

 

 

Academic Support for Students

Research in education and cognitive psychology shows that durable, long-lasting learning typically requires effortful engagement and often involves setbacks. The key difference between successful and unsuccessful students is not whether they encounter challenges, but how they respond to them. Successful students make use of help and resources when they need them.

Struggling is a normal (and even expected) part of the learning process. If you are finding parts of this course difficult, please take advantage of the support and resources listed below.

 

Email Office Hours

Your instructor will answer emails at specified times throughout the week. However, please review the Policies about Email Communication section before sending an email.

 

In-Person Office Hours

Your lab instructors will hold weekly in-person office hours. The times and locations of these office hours are posted on the Instructor Office Hours page. 

In-person office hours are an excellent opportunity to receive help on an assignment or to ask questions and talk through your understanding of course concepts. In particular, if you have any Mathematica-related questions or need help with Mathematica code for an assignment, please consider attending the in-person office hours. 

 

Tutoring for Physics Majors and Minors

The physics department provides free tutoring sessions to physics majors and minors. The tutors are Virginia Tech graduate students who are well-versed in many of the physics and math undergraduate courses. 

The time and location of these tutoring sessions are listed below:

Policies about Email Communication

 

Overview

Before sending an email to the Lab Director or your instructor, you should review the syllabus, the Frequently Asked Questions Page, and all other resources on Canvas to determine if you can answer your own question. If these resources do not answer your question or address your concerns, please feel free to email the appropriate person. (Refer to the Person of Contact section below.)

The Lab Director and your instructor answer emails for this course at specified times during the week:

  • The Lab Director answers emails during their Email Office Hours, which are posted at the beginning of the syllabus.
  • Your instructor is expected to check and answer their emails for one hour each business day.

We will answer emails on a first-come-first-serve basis. Please allow the Lab Director and your instructor two business days to respond to your email.

 

 

Email Etiquette

All email communications in this course must conform to the following guidelines:

  • Sender's Email Address: Send an email using your VT email account. Do not use the Canvas messaging feature or a non-VT email account. 
  • Subject: In the subject line of your email, include your course number and lab CRN.
  • Salutation: Begin your message by addressing the recipient directly, such as, "Dear Dr. Jones," "Professor Williams," etc. 
  • Message: The message of your email should be clear and concise. Provide background information on yourself and the intent of your email. Use full sentences, proper grammar and capitalization, and appropriate spelling. 
  • Recipient's Email Address: Ensure that you address your email to the appropriate recipient by consulting the Person of Contact section below.
  • Respectfully Wait for a Response: Allow the Lab Director or your instructor two business days to respond to your email before sending a follow-up email.

These guidelines have been adapted from Pamplin College's Proper Email Etiquette guidelines. 

 

Person of Contact

Below is a list of common email subjects and the person to whom those emails should be addressed.

Subject of Email Person of Contact
Questions regarding a grade on an assignment Your lab instructor
Disputing a grade on an assignment Your lab instructor
Requests for assistance with an assignment. (Some restrictions apply. Refer to the Limitation of Email section below) Your lab instructor
Reporting a technical issue with an assignment The Lab Director
Questions about course policy The Lab Director
Requests for deadline extensions The Lab Director
Notifications about special accommodations The Lab Director
Requests to resolve a conflict between students, or between a student and their instructor.  The Lab Director
Requests to resolve an ongoing grading dispute between a student and an instructor. (Students must attempt to resolve a grading dispute with their instructor before involving the Lab Director) The Lab Director

 

 

Contact Information

Lab Director: Dr. Travis Merritt (tmerritt@vt.edu)

  • Office: 108A Robeson Hall

Lab Instructor: See Your Lab Instructor: Name and Email (by CRN) page

Limitations of Email

Requests for Assistance with an Assignment

Your best opportunity to ask your instructor questions is during the lab sessions.

We understand that students may have questions about an assignment even after attending their lab sessions. Therefore, requesting assistance for an assignment over email is permissible, albeit limited. Lab instructors set aside one hour every business day to answer student emails. During this time, they will answer any student's email. However, if their email volume is high, they must prioritize responding to emails concerning grades and grading disputes. 

Out of respect for your instructor's time,  please remember that your instructor is not "on-call" throughout the week. While your instructor wants to help you succeed in this course, they also deserve a work-life balance. Like most jobs, your instructor is contractually obligated to only work for a specified number of hours a week. These hours are primarily allocated to administering lab sessions and grading assignments.

Grades and Grading Policies

 

 

Graded Components

The following are the graded components for this course:

  1. Lab Check-ins
  2. Lab Assignments
  3. Homework Assignments

In general, your instructor grades each assignment according to a grading rubric generated by the Lab Director.  These rubrics establish performance expectations for student work and show students how to meet those expectations. They also disclose how each assignment will be graded. 

Students can view the rubric for an assignment immediately when the assignment is available on Canvas. You should review the rubrics before you begin any assignment in this course and use these rubrics to guide your work. To view a rubric for a particular assignment, follow these instructions. 

In addition to using rubrics to grade assignments, instructors will give students constructive comments about what they did well and what they need to improve. Your instructor is expected to provide comments for any grading criterion that receives a rating that is not Meets Expectations. To view your instructor's comments on an assignment, follow these instructions.

Your grade for each lab assignment will be posted on Canvas under Grades.  Your instructor is expected to grade lab assignments and post those grades on Canvas within one week of receiving those assignments. If this does not happen, discuss the matter with your instructor.  If, after contacting your instructor, this issue is still unresolved, please contact the Lab Director by email.

Your instructor will not drop any grades at the end of the term. 

 

 

The following subsections discuss grading-related policies that are specific to each graded component.

Lab Check-ins

Lab Check-ins are group assignments. All members who were present during a group's check-in will receive the same grade for the check-in.

(To clarify, there is nothing that students need to submit for lab check-ins.)

Lab Assignments

Lab Assignments are group assignments.  All members who contribute to the group's work on the assignment (e.g., experiments, lab notes, etc.) will receive the same grade for that assignment.  

The collaboration category for lab assignments is Category C: Group Assignment with Limited External Collaboration. Refer to the Student Conduct section in this syllabus for more information. 

Homework Assignments

Homework assignments are individual assignments. Every student must submit work for these assignments, and submissions are graded on an individual basis.   

The collaboration category for homework assignments is Category B: Individual Assignment with Limited Collaboration. Refer to the Student Conduct section in this syllabus for more information. 

 

Grace Period

To account for various technical issues that students may experience during the submission process, such as a temporary loss of internet access or submission errors, all assignments in this course have a 1-day grace period. In other words, students will be able to submit an assignment up to 1 day after the submission deadline without penalty. 

With that said, students should submit their work for an assignment by the deadline and only use the grace period to resolve technical issues or submission errors. I will not grant deadline extensions beyond the grace period for submission errors or short-term loss of internet access. 

Late Assignments 

If you submit an assignment within this grace period, Canvas will flag the submission as "Late." Based on how Canvas works, Canvas will automatically assign a grade of zero to your submission. However, your instructor will grade any work submitted within the grace period and will not apply any grading penalties. Fear not. 

 

 

Group Assignments

All members of a group will receive the same grade on a group assignment. 

For group assignments with online submissions, all members of a group can upload documents for the assignment. If a group makes multiple submissions for an assignment, the group can only see their most recent submission. Your instructor will grade your group's most recent submission.

Each group member is responsible for verifying that their group successfully uploaded work for a group assignment. If a group fails to submit a grade for an assignment, then the group will not receive credit for that assignment. For instance, if your group appoints one member to upload a submission, but that member fails to do so, then all members will receive a zero with no exceptions.

Therefore, around the deadline for a group assignment, I highly encourage you to verify that your group has successfully submitted work for that assignment. At this time, if you notice that there is no submission for your group, take the initiative and upload your group's work for that assignment.

To ensure that any member of the group has the ability to upload the group's work for an assignment at any time, use an online cloud service to share the group's work with all members. Do this during the lab sessions. 

 

Disputing Lab Grades

If you believe that your instructor improperly graded one of your assignments, you must first discuss the matter with your instructor. If you are unsatisfied with the outcome of that discussion, you may then contact the Lab Director. Students must initiate a grade dispute no more than one week after receiving that grade. 

 

 

Final Course Grade

Your final course grade is a weighted average of your coursework. The grade weights for each category of coursework are as follows:

Category

 

Weight

Lab Assignments

 

50%

Lab Check-ins

 

20%

Homework Assignments

 

30%

There is no final exam for this course. 

 

Your instructor will report your final course grade to the Lab Director at the end of the term. Then, the Lab Director will submit your final course grade to your physics lecture instructor.

 

 

Deadline Extensions

In general, you may not submit an assignment after the grace period has expired.

With that said, you may request a deadline extension if you cannot submit an assignment because of extenuating circumstances, such as

  • a medical-related absence,
  • accommodations for disabilities, or
  • a multi-day loss of internet service and an inability to travel to campus to use its internet.  (A submission error or short-term loss of internet service is not considered an extenuating circumstance. The grace period already accommodates these submission issues.)

Planned travel or events generally do not qualify for deadline extensions. If your plans occur during or around an assignment deadline, you should submit your work for the assignment before your planned travel or event.

Requesting a Deadline Extension

To request a deadline extension, contact the Lab Director by email. In your email, you must

  1. explicitly state for which assignments you need a deadline extension and
  2. include a PDF of any supporting documentation that corroborates your extenuating circumstance. This documentation must come from an official source such as a medical institution (e.g., a doctor's note, a record of a medical appointment), a University Office (such as the Dean of Students office), etc. 
If your supporting documentation is an email, you need to create a PDF of the document and email it directly to me. Please do not forward me the email.

If you do not yet have supporting documentation from a university office, then, in your email, state that you are in the process of obtaining documentation. Once you receive the documentation, send it to me, and I will extend your deadline.

Deadline for Deadline Extension Requests

You must request a deadline extension within 1 week after your extenuating circumstance has expired. For instance, if you were not able to submit an assignment due to a medical-related absence, then once you return from your absence, you have 1 week to request a deadline extension. 

 

Making Up Missed Lab Sessions

In general, if you miss a lab session, you cannot receive credit for the assignments associated with that session, such as the lab assignment and the lab check-in. 

With that said, you may request to make up the assignments if you cannot attend a lab session because of extenuating circumstances, such as medical-related absences, university-sanctioned absences, or accommodations for disabilities.

If you attended a lab session but failed to submit the session's assignment before the deadline, you need a deadline extension to receive credit for the assignment. You cannot request to make up the assignments in this case since you attended the lab session.

 

Requesting Make-up Assignments

To make up the assignments for a missed lab session, contact the Lab Director by email. In your email, you must

  1. explicitly state which lab session you missed (date of the session, unit number, etc.) and
  2. include supporting documentation that corroborates your extenuating circumstance. This documentation must come from a university office, such as the Dean of Students or Schiffert Health Center. (If you do not yet have supporting documentation, then, in your email, state that you are in the process of obtaining this documentation. Once you receive the documentation, send it to me.)

If I approve your request, I will give you access to make-up assignments. These make-up assignments are individual assignments that you will complete outside of the lab sessions. 

Deadlines for Make-up Requests

You must request to make up an assignment within 1 week after your extenuating circumstance has expired. For instance, if you were not able to attend a lab session due to a medical-related absence, then once you return from your absence, you have 1 week to submit the request.

 

Disability Accommodations

If you are a student with a disability or think you may have a disability, please contact the Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD) Office. The SSD Office works closely with students and faculty to identify reasonable accommodations that are appropriate for you. 

If you have already been approved for accommodations, the SSD office will send me, the Lab Director, a letter of accessibility through the Accessible Information Management (AIM) system. In addition, please review the Implementation Plan for Common SSD Accommodations page, which discusses how I implement common SSD accommodations in this course. If you have any questions or concerns regarding the implementation plan, or if the plan does not address your accommodations, please contact me. We can discuss your accommodations and develop a more suitable implementation plan for you.

 

 

Academic Integrity and Collaboration Rules

 

Honor Code

The Undergraduate Honor Code pledge that each member of the university community agrees to abide by states:

 

As a Hokie, I will conduct myself with honor and integrity at all times. I will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor will I accept the actions of those who do.

 

Students enrolled in this course are responsible for abiding by the undergraduate Honor Code on each assignment and/or exam. A student who has doubts about how the Honor Code applies to any assignment is responsible for obtaining specific guidance from the course instructor before submitting the assignment for evaluation. Students are strongly discouraged from misusing unauthorized online sources, including generative artificial intelligence outlets. Students are strongly encouraged to consult their faculty members regarding the use of such outside materials, as the misuse of these sources may constitute a violation of the Honor Code. Ignorance of the rules does not exclude any member of the University community from the requirements and expectations of the Honor Code.

To learn more about the Honor Code and acts that constitute academic misconduct, please read the Honor Code Policy and Manual.

 

 

Academic Integrity Policies for Assignment

All assignments submitted shall be considered "graded work. As such, the Honor Code applies to all aspects of your work for these assignments. 

 

Collaboration Policies

 

Learning is inherently a social activity. As such, most learning involves some degree of collaboration with your peers, teachers, community, and other scholars.

Students are often uncertain about which forms of collaboration are considered to be permissible academic conduct. Therefore, I have categorized all assignments in this course to explicitly communicate the extent to which you can collaborate with other students and incorporate the ideas and work of others into your own. 

The collaboration categories for assignments in this course are described below. Each assignment's collaboration category is specified in its description. 

  • Category A - Individual assignment without collaboration: You may not collaborate on this assignment with other students. You may not receive help from anyone except your instructors on these assignments. Every aspect of the work that you submit must be attributable to you. 
  • Category B - Individual assignment with limited collaboration: You may collaborate on this assignment with your classmates, albeit in a limited capacity. You may share general information and discuss general concepts and approaches to the assignment with your classmates. However, the work that you submit must be in your own words, reflect your own thinking, and feature your own solutions. 
  • Category C - Group assignment with limited external collaboration: You may collaborate on this assignment with classmates external to your assigned group, albeit in a limited capacity. You may share general information and discuss general concepts and approaches to the assignment with external classmates. However, the work that your group submits must be attributable to your group, reflect your group's thinking, contain data that your group has collected (except for data provided to you by the instructor), and feature your own solutions. 

 

AI Policy

In this course, the use of generative AI tools is permitted for all assignments, given that you use the AI tool to contribute to their learning of the course content, but not to replace original work. You must properly acknowledge when and how AI tools have been used in your submissions. Failure to disclose AI use or submitting AI-generated work as entirely your own without critical engagement will constitute a violation of the Honor Code. If you are ever unsure whether a particular use of AI is permitted, it is your responsibility to ask your instructor before proceeding.

 

Explicitly Prohibited Practices

The following practices constitute academic misconduct under the Honor Code and the policies of this course. They are listed here explicitly to remove any ambiguity regarding their prohibition.

  • Use of online tutoring or Q&A sites: You may not consult online tutoring services or question-and-answer platforms (e.g., Chegg, Course Hero, Coursera, Google Drive, etc.) for any coursework in this class.

  • Improper use of AI tools: You may not submit AI-generated work as your own or use AI tools without proper disclosure and critical engagement. 

 

 

 

Summary: Student Responsibilities

  • Read the syllabus. The policies in this syllabus take precedence over any commitments that your lab instructor has made. The Lab Director is the final interpreter of the policies in this syllabus.

  • Before your lab sessions, review the lab assignment. This pre-session review will allow your group to use their lab session time more efficiently. 

  • Arrive at your lab session on time. If you are more than 10 minutes late for the lab session, you cannot attend the lab session.

  • Before attempting an assignment, review the grading rubric for that assignment. These rubrics establish performance expectations for student work and disclose how your instructor will grade submissions. To view the rubric for a particular assignment, follow these instructions.

  • At the beginning of your lab session, review your Canvas Group Set for the session and ensure that you are in the correct group. If you are in the wrong group, move yourself to the correct group. Unless you are absent, your instructor will not modify your Canvas Group Set. 
  • Follow the instructions for each assignment. This includes verifying that you have correctly and successfully submitted your work for an assignment. 

  • You should use the entire lab session to work on a lab assignment. Unless you receive permission from your instructor, you should not leave the lab session before it has ended. 

  • Submit your work for an assignment by the deadline. The grace period is intended to help students resolve temporary technical issues that may arise during the submission process. Unless the Lab Director has given you a deadline extension, your instructor will not accept assignments after the grace period has expired.

  • Abide by the collaboration policies for this course.

  • Periodically check the grade book in Canvas to ensure that your instructor has correctly entered your grades in the grade book. If the grade for one of your assignments is missing,  you need to promptly report the grade discrepancy to your instructor.

assignments.name: Intro
assignments.description:
Submission

  • Go to your class's Activities folder
  • Go to the Wikipedia Intros folder
  • Create a document there
  • Name the document like this: Last Name, First Name - Intro
  • Follow the instructions below

Instructions

Mimic the purpose, focus, structure, and style of a Wikipedia entry to introduce yourself to the class in about 300 words. In addition to the standard opening section, have at least one heading (like "Early Life" in the example linked below).

Example: Bob RossLinks to an external site.

Points of Emphasis

  • Purpose: Your rhetorical purpose is to help readers get to know you a little bit because you'll be working with people in the class for four months.
  • Genre: You should make several choices based on the genre "Wikipedia entry."
  • Audience: You should also make choicessuch as what information to includebased on the fact that you're writing this for other students in this class and me, the instructor.
  • Development: Choose what to focus on about yourself, but include specifics (like the dates and TV show title in the Ross example).
  • Structure: Notice that a Wikipedia entry usually begins with one overall statement, then provides a little more detail in the overview section at the top, then features more focused sections under headings. Fulfill that convention of the genre.
  • Style: Your language should sound like a Wikipedia entry. Notice the key characteristics of that style and tailer your writing to match it.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

We aren't meeting for class today. Please read chapter 1 ("Thinking Rhetorically") in our textbook, Everyone's an Author. Then do this:

  • Pick any section (like "First, Listen" or "What Do You Thinkand Why?").
  • Write the section title as a heading in a document you can submit here on Canvas.
  • Under that heading, share a specific experience you've had that relates to the focus of that section, explaining how it relates. (About 150 words.)
  • Then do that again for another section.

Evaluation

You should submit a single document with two separate, labeled responses. I'll grade your submission based on its overall quality, with an emphasis on these things:

Development: Be specific and detailed; the experience you write about should be clear and clearly related to the indicated section of the textbook. 

Structure: Organize your responses carefully so that one thing leads to another and it all reads smoothly.

Style: Write this in a conversational style, like you're talking to a friend.

Design: Your document should two headings with about 150 words written under each one.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

assignments.name: Argument Prewriting
assignments.description:
Resources

  • Read the Argument project assignment
  • Read Chapter 3, "Rhetorical Situations," in Everyone's an Author (starts on p. 30)
  • Read the "Arguing a Position/A Roadmap" in Everyone's an Author (starts on p. 174)

Assignment

  • In your class's Argument Work folder, go to the subfolder with the same name as this assignment
  • Create a document. Name it like this: Last Name, First Name - Argument Prewriting
  • Copy this template
  • Paste the template into your prewriting document
  • Keeping the Argument essay assignment, the textbook material, and our in-class discussions in mind, fill out the template with a lot of developed, detailed material
    • The idea is to generate (a) many thoughts about and (b) a lot of material for your essay. Generate more stuff than you'll probably need for the actual essay. 
  • Delete all of my prompts & questions, leaving only the various headings/subheadings and your very developed notes

Instructions given and activities completed during class.

Workshop

  • Add 1 comment to your partner's document to address whether or not they seem to be on track to create an essay that fits the assignment expectations as you understand them.
  • Add 4 other comments to help the writer generate additional ideas for what they could include in their essay.

assignments.name: Argument Drafted Portion 1
assignments.description: In your class's Argument Work folder, open the Argument Drafting folder and create a document, use our usual titling convention, and draft about 600 words of your Argument essay. That should be about half of the essay.

Attendance is required for credit on in-class activities.

Workshop

Each comment should have:

  • Label: Development, Structure, or Style
  • Resource Quote: Brief, focused quote from the Argument assignment, a class slideshow, or the textbook
  • Feedback: Developed, specific feedback that fits the label and relates to the resource quote

Note: You should add 4 comments to your partner's draft2 Development, 1 Structure, 1 Style.

Example comment

Style

"An informal and conversational style may endear you to readers and help them feel welcome and engaged" (Argument Instruction, par 13).

I like the way you state your criteria, its very clear, but there's a slight difference in tone, between this paragraph and some of the preceding paragraphs, this paragraph is more formal. Consider making it a bit more informal.

assignments.description:

NOTE: Please do not resolve any comments from the previous workshop; make all revisions in your own copy elsewhere and leave shared documents as they are forever.

assignments.description:
In your class's Argument WorkLinks to an external site. folder, open the Argument - Meta Draft for Workshop folder and create a document, use our usual titling convention, and follow these insturctions:

Revise your drafted Argument essay to make it excellent. Add 4 footnotes. Each footnote should include:

  • A label identifying what element of your essay you're focused on: Development, Structure, Style, Design (have one footnote for each of those labels)
  • A brief, focused quote from a course resource (discussion, feedback, textbook, Canvas material, slideshow, etc.)
  • Explain the rationale for a specific choice you made as a writer of the essay, using rhetorical terminology (genre, purpose, audience, etc.) to demonstrate a strong grasp of the course content and your own rhetorical choices within the assigned rhetorical situation.

See the Argument Examples folder for an example of a meta draft.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

assignments.name: Argument - Meta Draft
assignments.description:
This "Meta" version of Argument your essay should be thoroughly revised and include 4 footnotes.

Each footnote should include:

  • A label identifying what element of your essay you're focused on: Development, Structure, Style, Design (have one footnote for each of those labels)
  • A brief, focused quote from a course resource (discussion, feedback, textbook, Canvas material)
  • Explain the rationale for a specific choice you made as a writer of the essay, using rhetorical terminology (genre, audience, etc.) to demonstrate a strong grasp of the course content and your own rhetorical choices within the assigned rhetorical situation.

See the Argument Examples folder for examples of meta drafts, but keep in mind that those students were not required to quote course material in their footnotes.

Evaluation

Essay (2 pts)

I'll evaluate the essay itself based on its Development, Structure, Style, and Design with a consideration of the resources available to you, including course materials, workshop feedback, and time. This draft should be better than your earlier drafted material and showcase an evolution based on feedback you've received and your ability to self-critique and improve your work. 

Footnotes (2 pts)

I'll evaluate the footnotes based on their development, depth, focus, and clarity. You should demonstrate a thorough and nuanced understanding of many rhetorical concepts as well as full comprehension of your rhetorical situation for this argument essay. You should address a variety of rhetorical choices and concepts. Each footnote should include a portion of quoted material from course content, as noted in the instructions above. Ultimately, your footnotes should all work together to showcase your excellent understanding of rhetoric and how your work on this essay relates to rhetoric and points of emphasis that we've focused on throughout the project.

assignments.name: Argument - Presentation
assignments.description:
Before Class

Presentation Prep

Go to your class's Argument Presentation folder, create a slideshow, and prepare a presentation to fulfill the requirements below.

Your slideshow should be complete and added to  to an external site.the Argument Presentation folder by the deadline for this assignment; you'll present during class that week.

During Class

Presentation

1.5-2 minutes presenting; 1.5-2 minutes leading discussion. Total time should be 3-4 minutes.

Present an argument while fulfilling all of the "Characteristic Features" of an argument covered in chapter 13 (pg. 158-171). The subject of your presentation may be related to the subject of your argument essay, but you should present a different argument; make this a new, fresh opinion that you're defending. 

Conclude your argument with a discussion question that could lead the class to an interesting conversation.

Presentation Evaluation

Basic Public Speaking Skills

  • Speak at an appropriate volume
  • Speak clearly
  • Do not read your presentation, though you can use notes
  • Keep your head up
  • Don't present to the screen, floor, ceiling, or walls present to your audience
  • Present to everybody in the room, not just me or one segment of your audience
  • Avoid repetitive verbal and physical behaviors, such as hand clapping, saying uh, touching your face too much, swaying, shifting from foot to foot, fidgeting with your notecards, pacing back and forth, etc.
  • Dont lock your knees. People have passed out from that (Ive heard).
  • Control your speaking pace

Content

The presentation should have these characteristics:

  • Purposeful & Focused - Prepare, practice, and deliver a strong presentation
  • Organized - Includes the required points of emphasis in an orderly structure
  • Detailed - specifics specifics specificsthat's what works in communication

The ideal performance will be a confident, energetic, and personable delivery of developed, organized, and meaningful material that aligns with the bulleted list aboveand will obviously be tailored to the real audience in the room.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

Attendance is required for credit on in-class work.

Today's journal prompt: In about 200 words, respond to a classmate's presentation with your own argument. Choose a presentation that you disagree with and lay out your own counterargument or choose a presentation you agree with but make a different argument to support that position. In either case, refer to 1 or 2 specific points the presenter made, using their slideshow to refresh your memory about specific material in their argument.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

assignments.name: Narrative Prewriting
assignments.description:
Read the Narrative assignment thoroughly. Read this student example. Now develop a bunch of ideas for how you'll create your own excellent essay by doing this:

  • At the top of your Prewriting document, type "Prewriting" and designate it as "Heading 1"
  • Copy the contents of the Narrative Prewriting template
  • Paste that under your Prewriting heading in your document.
  • Follow all the instructions in the template and delete them, leaving the headings and the material you develop under each heading.
  • You should end up with at least 1,000 words, including the headings and excluding the instructions, which should be deleted.

Instructions given and activities completed during class. Attendance required for credit.

Watch this clip from Seinfeld. Pretend you're Jerry (the guy). Write the scene in 1st person, focusing on factors that affected your (Jerry's) rhetorical choices and how you communicated. Practice correct dialogue formatting. You don't have to write the whole thing; make it about 150 words, including vivid, relevant sensory details and at least four lines of dialogue.

assignments.name: Narrative Draft - Scenes 1 & 2
assignments.description:
• Read the Narrative assignment, the textbook's Narrative: Characteristic Features (200-209) & Narrative Roadmap (220-224), and these student examples. You should have a complete understanding of the essay you drafting.
  • Create a document in your class's Narrative Drafting folder.
  • Title your document in the usual way: Last, First - Narrative Drafting.
  • In that document, draft the first two scenes of your narrative essay. Keep these things in mind:
    • you should not have a typical introduction. Instead, just dive directly into the meaningful part of the first scene;
    • focus on the factors that affect how you communicate and the way you communicate;
    • include vivid details so that readers can really imagine the experience, emphasizing details that are related to the factors that affect your communication;
    • include dialogue and practice good principles of dialogue formatting and style; and
    • you should draft 600-800 words total for these two scenes.

Instructions given and activities completed during class.

For 1:25 class:

  • Add 5 comments to your partner's drafted scenes, one for each of these points of emphasis:
    • Focus - Is the material focused enough on sharing insights about the writer's communication?
    • Details - Are the details (a) vivid because they help you imagine the events and (b) relevant because they're related to the writer's communication in the scene?
    • Structure - Is the material in chronological order, meaning that you learn about the factors that affect their communication before they communicate (at least most of the time)?
    • Idiolect - What can the writer do to achieve a more distinctive, personalized voice?
    • Dialogue - Is the dialogue formatted properly according to the guidelines noted in the dialogue slideshow?
  • For each comment:
    • use the bolded word as a label
    • quote the Narrative assignment
    • give feedback in a developed, specific thought

This "Meta" version of your Narrative essay should be thoroughly revised and include 4 footnotes. Each footnote should include (1) a labelDevelopment, Structure, Style, or Design; (2) a precisely focused and relevant quote from a course resource (textbook, slideshow, feedback, etc.); and (3) a well-developed, insightful explanation of a specific choice you made as a writer and how that choices was influenced by one or more key aspects of your rhetorical circumstances. 

Evaluation

Essay (2 pts)

I'll evaluate the essay itself based on its Development, Structure, Style, and Design given the resources and opportunity you've had to make the essay excellent. This draft should be better than your previous drafted material and showcase an evolution based on your own assessment and feedback you've received throughout the project. 

Footnotes (2 pts)

I'll evaluate the footnotes based on their development, depth, focus, and clarity. Ultimately, your footnotes should all work together to showcase your excellent understanding of rhetoric and how your work on this essay relates to rhetoric and writing points of emphasis that we've focused on throughout the project.

The best footnotes will have a label, resource quote, and choice explanation that all match and are all tightly focused. Don't mismatch the elements, don't quote too much from a resource, and don't lose focus in your explanation. The best explanations will be focused, will be specific about the choice you made as a writer, and will explain why you made that choice by being specific about a key factor in your rhetorical circumstances. Additionally, the four explanations will cover a variety of rhetorical matters by (a) properly distinguishing between development, structure, style, and design to achieve proper focus in each case and (b) by connecting choices to a variety of factors in your rhetorical circumstances.

Overview

Give a 2-3 minute narrative presentation. Tell your actual audiencethe people in the room when you presenta story that they'll find engaging, interesting, entertaining, meaningful. 

Your presentation should showcase an understanding of the Characteristic Features of a narrative discussed in Chapter 15 of the textbook (pages 200-209). Don't consider that a prescribed organization. Formulate an effective structure to enhance your audience's experience. 

This should not be the same story you're writing about for your Narrative essay. 

By the deadline for this assignment

In your classes Narrative Presentation folder, create a slideshow that features no text and 5-10 original images. "Original" here means you should create the images or own the rights to them, whether they're your own artwork or pictures or whatever. You can't use images found online.  

The slideshow should be complete and in the folder by the deadline of this assignment on Canvas; you'll present the next day in class.

 to an external site.

assignments.name: Analysis - Review
assignments.description:
Instructions

In your class's Analysis Review folder and with your assigned group, help prepare a slideshow I can use to teach a review of the analysis project.

  • Cover the points of emphasis listed below and follow the instructions for each one.
  • You may use multiple slides to cover one point of emphasis.
  • All examples should come from your group's drafted essays. Here are the slides you should include and instructions for each one:

Points of Emphasis

  • Development: Claims
    • Provide a good example of a well-written precise claim and explain why it's good.
    • Provide an example of a precise claim that needs revision, concisely explain why it needs to be revised, and provide a revised version.
  • Development: Evidence
    • Provide a good example of evidence that includes vivid description.
    • Provide a good example of evidence that includes quoted language.
    • Provide an example of evidence that needs revision, concisely explain why it needs to be revised, and provide a revised version.
  • Structure: Analytical Paragraph
    • Provide an example of a body paragraph that needs structural revision with the disorganized portion in red text.
    • Provide a revised version of that same paragraph with each sentence labelled according to the structure guide.
  • Structure: Introduction
    • Provide an example of a properly structured introductory paragraph with each sentence labelled according to the structure guide.
  • Structure: Conclusion
    • Provide an example of a properly structured concluding paragraph with each sentence labelled according to the structure guide.
  • Style: Quoting
    • Provide a good example of each of these:
      • tagged quote
      • blended quote
      • colon quote
    • Provide an example of a sentence that includes quoted material but needs revision, concisely explain why it needs to be revised, and provide a revised version. 
  • Style: Sentence Variety
    • Provide an example of a paragraph with good sentence variety; isolate each sentence; put the number of words for each sentence in parentheses after it; turn the opening element of each sentence green; and turn all the punctuation orange. That way, it should be easy to immediately see how dissimilar the sentences are. 

Evaluation

Everyone in the group gets the same grade, which will be based on two major factors: the quality of your examples, which means they need to demonstrate a thorough understanding of the relevant course content; and the presentation of the slides, which means they need to function well as presentable examples projected on screen in the classroom during a lesson.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.
