assignments.name: Analysis - Presentation
assignments.description:
Prep

We won't use slideshows this time.

Instead, you'll practice a kind of presentation that's common for academics: reading developed, detailed work. Write a review of anything you choose, using the textbook's Characteristic Features of a review (beginning on page 338) as a guide for what kind of material you should include.

As always, your audience is the actual people in the room. But this time our emphasis is on the fact that everyone in the room is an academic.

You are welcome to read as much as or as little as you want, but the stuff you say should be clear, insightful, perceptive, organized, specific, and articulate. Reading may help you achieve that level of quality for the content of your presentation. Whether you're reading or not, the goal is to deliver the review as smoothly and engagingly as possible. Give your audience a good experience with the performance of your presentation.

Your written review should probably be 250-300 wordsmake sure you can read it in 2-3 minutes.

Submit your written review to this assignment on Canvas. You'll present during a subsequent class meeting.

You have a 4-minute time slot. Present for 2-3 minutes. Answer 1 question from the audience. 

During Class

Presentation Evaluation

Basic Public Speaking Skills

  • Speak at an appropriate volume
  • Speak clearly
  • Make some eye contact with the entire audience
  • Avoid repetitive verbal and physical behaviors, such as hand clapping, saying uh, touching your face too much, swaying, shifting from foot to foot, fidgeting with anything, etc.
  • Dont lock your knees. People have passed out from that (Ive heard).
  • Control your pacing

Content

The presentation should have these characteristics:

  • Purposeful & Focused - Prepare, practice, and deliver a strong presentation
  • Organized - Includes the elements in the textbooks Characteristic Features in an orderly structure
  • Detailed - specifics specifics specificsthat's what works in communication

The ideal performance will be a confident, energetic, and personable delivery of developed, organized, and meaningful material that is tailored to the academic audience in the room.

Penalties

  • -.10 per 15 seconds outside of the assigned presentation time range (e.g. 90 seconds = -.2)
  • -.10 for each instance of inconsiderate behavior while people are presenting. I judge what's inconsiderate. This may include talking, looking at your phone, having your laptop open, listening to headphones, dozing off, etc. No warnings. Just don't do that stuff and you won't lose points for it.

We are all limited in our ability to perceive and comprehend the world, so we rely on others to provide information, ideas, and inspiration we can use to live well. No matter what you personally believe, it's pretty clear that we're inundated with bad information, bad ideas, bad influences. Even if you're confident that you're navigating all of that excellently, other people obviously aren't: there's a lot of pain and suffering in the world. So there seems to be a need for moreand more effectivegood things: movies, TV shows, music, books, games, social media posts, videos, classes, conversations, people, etc. 

This journal entry should be longer than usual500 words, totaland you should focus on two topics:

One, tell me about stuff out in the world that you think offers people something good. I'm talking good information, ideas, and/or inspiration. It can be a piece of media, like a podcast, or something more conceptual, like meditation, or something more mundane, like dogs.

What is it? Why do you know about it? Why is it good? Write about multiple things if you want. 

Two, tell me about what you could create to contribute something uniquely your own to a world that needs it. Think about your interests, experiences, perspectives, views, sensibility, and so onyou are a unique combination of stuff and therefore have an opportunity to create unique things to share with others. You can write about all kinds of stuff or focus on one thing. It can be any "medium," including day-to-day things like talking with friends or a big deal project like writing a novel. The challenge is to articulate what the unique combination of elements could be, what your vision for the thing is, and why you think it could be worth sharing.
Instructions given and activities completed during class.

assignments.name: Argument
assignments.description:
Submit a document with only your MLA-formatted final draft; no footnotes, no leftover comments, no headings from your work doconly the essay, properly formatted.

Overview: Make an argument to support your ranking of "items" that belong to a narrowly defined group. You'll need to support your argument by providing an evaluation of each "item," which will require clear criteria and evidence to support judgments. 

Examples: Shea Serrano's "The Basketball Scouting Report" and "To Me, You are Perfect." As long as you deliver a developed, well-crafted evaluation, you can deviate significantly from Serrano's example; it's just an example of how an evaluation can work. Here are a few student examples, as well.

Subject: You should define your subject narrowly so that your essay can be an in-depth and complete treatment of the subject. 

Audience: People who are very familiar with and enthusiastic about the subject. 

Research: This is not a research essay and no "heavy" research is allowed. You should be able to develop your work thoroughly while drawing on only your own expertise. For example, if you're ranking songs on an album, obviously you'd quote lyrics. That's not "research" for our purposes. Contrastingly, it would not be permissible for you to include information gathered from newspapers or web pages to help you defend a point. Please talk to me as needed for guidance on this issue. 

Word Count: 1,000 to 1,200 words. 

Rhetorical Choices

Development

Focus on evaluating each "thing" by isolating and evaluating relevant elements quantitatively and qualitatively. A well-developed argument will have clear and varied criteria, precise statements about the quality of several elements, and detailed support for those statements and the overall "conclusions" of the evaluation, including clear reasoning for the order of your ranking. Note: If your evaluation is entirely objective/quantitative, then it doesn't need to be an essay and could be a table or chart instead. That's not good. You should include opinion and qualitative criteria. 

Develop each part of your essay proportionally. The parts dont have to be the same length; instead, the length and amount of detail for each part should be based on how important it is to your purpose and/or how complex it is. More space devoted to complicated but significant material makes sense. A lot of space wasted on simple and/or insignificant material doesn't.

RUBRIC: Development

Excellent: Demonstrates a high level of sophistication and nuance; major themes and ideas fully explored/supported through relevant specifics to achieve depth and substance.  

Possible issues: Major themes and/or ideas not complexly explored or rendered; includes specifics/details that dont serve the overall purpose of the work effectively; irrelevant, inappropriate, or otherwise insufficient material; achieves only basic depth or complexity. 

Structure

Organize your evaluation as a ranking in order from worst to best. Alternatively, you can organize your evaluation as a group of "candidates" that you narrow down by eliminating some based on a sequence of criteria (like Serrano's "To Me..." and the Wilson essay in the student examples linked above). Sections and paragraphs should be organized carefully to avoid repetitive material and other structural issues. Generally, deliver your material in a careful order so that readers can move from point to point fluidly and with no confusion.

RUBRIC: Structure

Excellent: Features only relevant parts in an order that optimizes reader experience and fully serves the purpose of the work, including an organization of topics/ideas that facilitates reader comprehension and intrigueat all levels: overall and within paragraphs. 

Possible issues: Irrelevant parts; disruptive flow of parts, such as scattering a topic across multiple paragraphs/sections when that topic would ideally be gathered into one paragraph/section; repeating ideas rather than progressing through focused points methodically; disorganized paragraphs that create a herky jerky sequence of material rather than a streamlined progression.

Style & Language-Level Conventions

Achieve a consistent, purposeful style while following general principles of grammar, mechanics, usage, and spelling to ensure comprehension. You have some flexibility here. An informal and conversational style may endear you to readers and help them feel welcome and engaged. However, an elevated, more formal style may help you seem authoritative. Strike a balance between totally conversational and totally "academic," controlling your writing at the language level to present yourself as friendly, intelligent, and skilled.

RUBRIC: Style

Excellent: Includes a wide variety of sentence structures and word choices to create a tonally consistent and rhetorically effective voice while maintaining superb clarity; note that perfect grammar isnt necessary for all genres and audiencesinstead, the goal is to use language carefully to create desired rhetorical effects within a particular context.  

Possible issues: Style may not fit the genre or audience; repetitive choices regarding sentence structures; misused words; stylistic choices that may compromise the rhetorical integrity of the work, such as offensive language; issues with grammar and mechanics that disrupt reader experience and detract from the rhetorical effectiveness of the writing; inconsistency.

Design

Your final draft should meet the guidelines of the MLA handbook, 9th Edition. See this sample paper for guidance.

RUBRIC: Design

Excellent: All material presented with proper formattingsee MLA 9th edition guidelines, using Purdue OWL as a resourceand in an orderly layout with clear labels, headings, and so on as needed for optimized reader navigation.

Possible issues: Lacks adherence to MLA standards; jumbled elements and/or unlabeled elements where labels are needed for clarity and navigability; sloppy presentation. 

Final Draft Submission

Submit only your final draft to this assignment on Canvas.

assignments.name: Narrative
assignments.description:
Your final draft should be submitted as a properly formatted Word document with no footnotes or comments.

Overview

Write a personal narrative narrowly focused on varied rhetorical situations associated with an activity you love.

Your Rhetorical Circumstances for This Essay

Exigence

Even though we all make choices about how to talk or write all the time, we dont often think consciously about the rhetorical elements that influence how we communicate. However, if we all become more aware of how we communicate, we might communicate more effectively in our everyday lives.

So basically: A lot of people dont think about this stuff.

Audience

Your classmates in English 1105. The idea is that you are all learning about rhetoric, paying attention to your own choices, and sharing essays about those choices to help each other understand rhetoric in everyday life better and better.

Constraints

Constraints are factors that affect what's possible for the communicator. As the writer of this essay, you have to make effective choices within a complex set of factors that come from various aspects of your writing context, including cultural issues, subject choice, genre, audience, and yourself.

The narrowly defined genre you're working in could be called "narrative about everyday rhetoric for Hooper's ENGL 1105." That means that you need to craft your essay in alignment with the many guidelines provided in these instructions and all of the course resources available to you, including in-class instruction, feedback, the textbook, and so on. 

The final draft: 1200-1500 words; MLA page formatting.

You cannot do research; everything must be based on your own knowledge and memory.

Your audience also introduces constraints to your rhetorical situation. Think about what they want, enjoy, understand, care about, etc. All of their preferences, interests, competencies, and so on are factors that you have to work with as you make choices, so those are constraints.

You may also find that you have "internal" constraints, factors that are part of your rhetorical situation because they are a part of you. For example, if you don't know how to format dialogue, you'll need to learn that in order to expand what's possible for you as a writer. 

Purpose

To help ENGL 1105 students gain a better understanding of how a person navigates a variety of rhetorical situations through your own specific example.

Genre

A personal narrative. Genre conventions include specific scenes with relevant and vivid details and a distinctive first-person voiceuse your idiolect.

Generally, a narrative is structured in chronological order, though you may experiment with alternative structures with good reason.

Its valuable to break free from your preconceived notions about what a school writing assignment should be. This is a series of vivid, narrative scenes, not an academic paper. It should be written more like a short story than a term paper. As always, a change in your rhetorical circumstancesincluding genrerequires a change to your rhetorical choices. 

Subject & Developing Your Material

Your broader subject is "How I communicate during this activity I love." Your essay should be made of 3 scenes that emphasize and explore your rhetorical choices and behaviors in distinct rhetorical situations that are a part of the activity. Basically, this essay will be a series of scenes intended to showcase how you communicate, emphasizing details related to how specific constraints affected how you communicate, and all the scenes are tied together by the activity. 

Each scene should make these things clear to your readers:

  • What are you trying to accomplish through communication?
  • Who do you communicate with and what about that audience affects your rhetorical choices?
  • Why do you communicate the way you do? Consciously or otherwise, what factors influence your rhetorical actions?
  • What do you do and say specifically to communicate? This should include dialogue as well as details related to tone, inflection, nonverbal communication, and anything else that's relevant to conveying and exploring how you communicated in the scene.
  • What are the results? Each scene should have some kind of closure or ending. Did you get what you wanted? Did you realize something? Did your rhetorical actions work?

Focus

Proportionally, the focus should remain on rhetoric, not simply explaining the event. The activity itself isn't the point. How you communicate is the point. The activity provides some of the context for that communication. As you develop the narrative, think of it as telling a story about how you communicate and keep your focus on rhetoric.

Depth

One of the most important habits to develop as a writer in academia is to narrow the scope of your subject so that you can dig into it more deeply. In this case, you dont want a bunch of unrelated scenarios. Instead, the scenes should add up to something comprehensive and complete. So you need to formulate a narrower focus that will allow you to more thoroughly break down and explore the subject. One way to think of it is to focus on how two constraints interact with each other, then pick scenes that include variations on those constraints.

Depth Example

Basketball Playing basketball Playing pickup basketball Interacting with teammates and opponents at pickup games 

Pickup communication  (x) other people's perceived respect for me + (y) my emotions  

How (x) my perception of my audience's respect for me interacts with (y) my emotions to affect (z) how I talk to people at a pickup basketball game.

That's a pretty narrow focus that I can explore deeply by including specific scenes that involve different degrees of perceived respect and different emotions; those two variables will be related (disrespect makes me mad); and that will affect how I communicate with people. 

Complexity

Often, complexity comes from addressing a variety of elements within a narrowly defined subject and how those elements compare and contrast or otherwise relate to each other. Within your narrow focus, you need to write about a variety of scenarios. That variety can come from changing variables like these:

  • Circumstances: writing vs speaking; different audiences; different genres; different aspects of who you are; different environmentsyou need to focus on a variety of constraints. Rhetorical contexts are dynamic and factors "interact" with each othervary the factors that interact with the constraint you're focused on.
  • Choices: even within similar circumstances, youve probably made different choices or tried different rhetorical tactics. You can use that variety to create a more complex essay. In that case, account for why you tried different options at different times.
  • Outcomes: sometimes you did a good job, other times you messed up; explore how you chose wisely or poorly, depending on the specific rhetorical factors in each situation.

Ultimately, variety and specifics will help you develop a richly complex, nuanced essay.

Complexity Example

Since I'm focused on (x) respect from audience, (y) my emotions, and (z) how I communicate as a result, I need to choose scenes that include (x) different levels of respect and, relatedly, (y) different emotions; if those things are different, I'll probably (z) communicate differently. So I'll have variety, but it's all focused on my key question: how does perceived respect relate to my emotions, and how does that affect my communication at a pickup basketball game?

So I'd pick:

  • joking around with respectful friend who puts me at ease;
  • arguing with friend over a call, and I'm not upset because I think this guy respects me; 
  • disrespectful guy I don't know talking trash, so I get angry and yell at him.

Reflection

Your varied scenes should culminate in a substantial reflection on your specific focus. What insights can you provide about your experiences and how they relate to each other? What have you come to realize about yourself and communication and life after thinking through the rhetorical aspects of this activity? This concluding reflection should grow out of but expand your narrow focus. One way to think about it is that your scenes explore one focused example of bigger ideas, considerations, realizations, and/or inquiries into the nature of life as a person who communicates. 

To be clear, you can and should weave in some reflection as you go, but the essay should end with a conclusive, fresh, interesting final reflection. Touch on aspects of your reflection along the way, planting seeds for the reflection that can grow out of the narrative and conclude it with substantive insight.

Reflection Example

Reflecting on my essay subject, I'll realize that some key contextual stuffconstraintsare important, like the fact that I was already depressed when I showed up to play and the fact that I valued this regular pickup game as a friendly, comfortable place to interact with people. So the guy talking trash ruined something important to me at a vulnerable time in life. Throughout the essay, I'll make sure to include details to help my readers understand my emotional state and all that, and then I'll end the essay with some comprehensive thoughts on taking care of my mental health so that I can more safely enjoy activities with others.  

Your Rhetorical Choices for This Essay

Development

Generally, youre trying to develop a thorough, interesting collection of observations about how you communicate in a variety of circumstances related to an activity you love. So: 

  • Narrow your focus so that all of your material works cohesively to complexly break down specific points of interest. 
  • Focus on 3 fully rendered, relevant scenes. A "scene" means an isolated event/experience that could be filmed and played for an audience in real time. You may need to summarize some stuff, but the essay should be mostly three immersive scenes with details and dialogue and the concluding reflection, not a bunch of summary.
  • The scenes should work together to highlight the multifaceted relationships between rhetorical circumstances, rhetorical choices, and rhetorical outcomes.
  • Separately, each scene should feature unique elementsdont repeat points. Each scene should: 
    • establish a clear set of circumstances that influence your choices;
    • include details about how you communicatedwhat you said/wrote, how, why, etc.;
    • note the results of your communication
    • all of which should be vividly rendered with relevant details
  • Draw connections between the scenes to explore the "dimensions" of your subject so that the parts add up to a complex treatment of the subject.
  • Conclude with a substantive, thoughtful, insightful reflection that emerges from your specific subject and connects it to bigger thoughts on life and communication.
  • Make sure to develop each part of your essay proportionally. The parts dont have to be the same length; instead, the length and amount of detail for each part should be based on how important it is to your purpose and/or how complex it is. More space devoted to complicated but significant material makes sense. A lot of space wasted on simple and/or insignificant material doesn't.

RUBRIC: Development

Excellent: Demonstrates a high level of sophistication and nuance; major themes and ideas fully explored/supported through relevant specifics to achieve depth and substance.  

Possible issues: Major themes and/or ideas not complexly explored or rendered; includes specifics/details that dont serve the overall purpose of the work effectively; irrelevant, inappropriate, or otherwise insufficient material; achieves only basic depth or complexity. 

Structure

  • Deliver your material in a careful order so that readers can move from point to point smoothly, without confusion. 
    • In narrative, readers should understand why a "character" is doing something when they do it, not afterwards; so one specific thing to do with the structure within scenes is to establish relevant constraints/factors before we see your rhetorical behavior. Generally, you should not explain the why after you describe the what because that means your audience has to read moments they don't actually understand until you explain them later.
  • Consider these factors: 
    • chronology
    • complexity (might go from "simple" to "complex")
    • relationships between parts (to facilitate transitions and to build complexity as the essay progresses)
  • Do not include a traditional introduction or conclusion. They dont fit the genre. Your structure should be scene, scene, scene, reflection. 

RUBRIC: Structure

Excellent: Features only relevant parts in an order that optimizes reader experience and fully serves the purpose of the work, including an organization of topics/ideas that facilitates reader comprehension and intrigueat all levels: overall and within paragraphs. 

Possible issues: Irrelevant parts; disruptive flow of parts, such as scattering a topic across multiple paragraphs/sections when that topic would ideally be gathered into one paragraph/section; repeating ideas rather than progressing through focused points methodically; disorganized paragraphs that create a herky jerky sequence of material rather than a streamlined progression.

Style & Language-Level Conventions

  • Idiolect. Write in your own voice because this essay is about you, your experiences, and how you think and feel. That means you can and should write in an informal voice. Find your idiolect.
  • Vivid & relevant details. Use vivid word choices & provide relevant details to help bring your experiences to life for your readers (thatll serve your purpose). Focus especially on (a) vivid verbs and (b) precise nouns that help readers understand your communication and its contexts. Adjectives and adverbs are fine but shouldn't be a substitute for stronger noun and verb choices. 
  • Dialogue. One kind of detail that's crucial to this project is dialogue. You should have properly formatted dialogue that sounds like real people talking to further immerse readers in the narrative and provide vivid examples of your communication.
  • Verb tense. Control your verb tenses to make sure that its always clear how things relate in time.
  • Sentence variety. Write in a variety of sentence types and constructions. 
  • Comprehensible grammar & mechanics. Even as you write informally in your own unique voice, adhere to the general principles of grammar, mechanics, usage, and spelling to ensure comprehension.

RUBRIC: Style

Excellent: Includes a wide variety of sentence structures and word choices to create a tonally consistent and rhetorically effective voice while maintaining superb clarity; note that perfect grammar isnt necessary for all genres and audiencesinstead, the goal is to use language carefully to create desired rhetorical effects within a particular context.  

Possible issues: Style may not fit the genre or audience; repetitive choices regarding sentence structures; misused words; stylistic choices that may compromise the rhetorical integrity of the work, such as offensive language; issues with grammar and mechanics that disrupt reader experience and detract from the rhetorical effectiveness of the writing; inconsistency.

Design

  • Your final draft should meet the guidelines of the MLA handbook, 9th Edition. See the blue boxes in this sample paper and Purdue OWL for guidance.
  • Your dialogue should be formatted properly. Use this slideshow as a resource.

RUBRIC: Design

Excellent: All material presented with proper formattingsee MLA 9th edition guidelines, using Purdue OWL as a resourceand in an orderly layout with clear labels, headings, and so on as needed for optimized reader navigation.

Possible issues: Lacks adherence to MLA standards; jumbled elements and/or unlabeled elements where labels are needed for clarity and navigability; sloppy presentation. 

Evaluation

The final draft is evaluated holistically with a consideration of the resources available to you, including these instructions, time, feedback, workshops, the textbook, lectures, discussions, etc.

assignments.name: Analysis
assignments.description:
Your Rhetorical Context

Exigence: Scholars need to understand how movies are marketed

With more movies than ever vying for an audience, media scholars are seeking to expand and deepen their understanding of how movie marketing showcases and deploys rhetorical strategies.

Rhetorical Purpose

To provide media scholars with insight into how movie marketing appeals to a target audience using rhetorical strategies.

Audience: Media scholars

Media scholars seeking fresh rhetorical analyses of movie marketing.

Genre: Rhetorical analysis

The purpose of a textual analysis is to share insights about a text's parts and how those parts work together. That means you should focus on relevant texts, make claims about features of the texts, and support those claims with evidence from the text. Specifically, you're writing a rhetorical analysis of texts, so you're task is to break down specific rhetorical elements of texts.

One convention of a rhetorical analysis is a methodical structure. The goal is to make sure readers always understand your point when they read it, which means you should first articulate a claim, then provide evidence to support that claim. For our work, you should organize your essay according to a prescribed structure, which you can find below.

Subject: The Rhetorical features of movie marketing

Marketing Materials

Choose a movie that was marketed in the recent past, focusing your analysis of its promotion on these texts:

  • one official poster
    • be careful about fan art and artwork that came out later; you need an official poster used when the movie was originally releasedlook for that block of credits and a release date
  • one official trailer
    • same here; people cut new trailers on YouTube, but you need an original, official trailer
  • one "print" interview with one or more people involved in making the movie, such as a star or director
    • articles that quote those people extensively count; reviews or other articles that are not serving promotion do not count
    • "print" means a written interview or articlevideos, podcasts, and other texts do not count, no exceptions

All of those should be from the time period associated with promotion of the movie. An actor talking about one of their old movies is no longer a matter of promotion; you're looking for interviews that exist because a person involved in making the movie is actively promoting it before or around the release date.

Rhetorical Elements

Youll analyze how the promotional materials indicate the movie's intended audience, including how they establish the movies genre, and how the marketing materials use ethos and pathos to persuade that intended audience to see the movie.

Note: One target audience for a movie is always fans of the genre, so you should devote space to explaining how the promotional materials convey the genre(s) of the movie. The strongest analyses will be able to identify additional groups, possibly defined by demographic characteristics such as age, gender, race, socioeconomic status, sociopolitical allegiance, education level. 

Note: Be very careful about how you focus your material. For example, it may make sense to identify "fans of the star" as an intended audience for the movie; however, you'll need to avoid 

NOTE: Go to your class's analysis folder, create your own individual folder there, and add each of your promotional texts to your individual folder (like I did in my folder).

Constraints

  • 1200-1500 words.
  • MLA page formatting.
  • The only sources allowed are the objects of analysis (poster, trailer, interview) and light research to support specific claims.
    • Consult me for guidance on research for this project
  • Genre Constraints
    • methodical structure 
    • break down texts to focus on specific elements
    • draw connections between elements
    • make specific claims/statements about texts
    • support claims with relevant, detailed evidence from texts
  • Subject Constraints
    • need a movie with promotional materials that will allow you to illustrate key rhetorical concepts
    • need to focus on audience, genre, pathos, and ethos
  • Audience Constraints
    • scholars, so they require depth, precision, incisveness, and a more formal, elevated writing style

Your Rhetorical Choices

Within the parameters of the rhetorical situation outlined above, execute effective rhetorical choices that align with the following expectations.

Development

  • Your analysis should be perceptive, revealing a strong comprehension of rhetorical concepts and the ability to apply those concepts insightfully and analytically.
  • Analytical claims should be articulated precisely. Following guidance provided during the unit, you should have broad claims and precise claims, all properly focused on rhetorical aspects of the movie marketing materials.
  • Claims should be supported persuasively by detailed evidence from the texts. Claims about visual or aural elements should be supported by vividly described details in the text. Claims about language should be supported by quoted portions of the text.
  • The space devoted to each topic should be proportional to the materials complexity and significance. In other words, dont over-develop one thing and under-develop another.

RUBRIC: Development

Excellent: A high level of sophistication and nuance; thorough understanding of rhetorical concepts; perceptive, astute claims; claims fully supported with relevant specifics to achieve depth and substance.  

Possible issues: Lacks details; insufficient evidence; misunderstands rhetorical concept(s); irrelevant, inappropriate, or otherwise insufficient material; achieves only basic depth or complexity. 

Structure

  • From sentence to sentence, clause to clause, phrase to phrase, paragraphs should be organized to progress from one point to the next as smoothly as possible.
  • Introduction should include:
    • context for your analysis
    • established significance of your work
    • an identification of your three texts
    • a preview of your essay structure
    • thesis statement
  • Analysis should include a section or paragraph for each key rhetorical concept.
    • The order that makes the most sense is: audience, genre, then ethos and pathos in whichever order
    • Within those segments, the structure should be:
      • a topic sentence that articulates a broad claim about the promotional campaign and a rhetorical concept
      • a precise claim about one text and one aspect of the relevant rhetorical concept, followed by detailed evidence
        • repeat the pattern of precise claim, then evidence, as needed to create a complex paragraph
      • the only other relevant material would be (a) context prior to evidence or (b) elaboration/explanation after evidencewhich should rarely be necessary
  • Conclusion should include:
    • a brief summary of your major points about this marketing campaign to synthesize all of your analysis into a single sentence
    • an acknowledgement of the limitations of your analysis (it's only one promotional campaign)
    • a suggestion for subsequent analysis that could be conducted
    • a final connection between your concluding material and your original context (from the introduction)

RUBRIC: Structure

Excellent: Features only relevant parts in an order that optimizes reader experience and fully serves the purpose of the work, including an organization of topics/ideas that facilitates reader comprehension and intrigueat all levels: overall and within paragraphs. Abides by the prescribed structure as outlined above and showcased in example essays.

Possible issues: Irrelevant parts; disruptive flow of parts, such as scattering a topic across multiple paragraphs/sections when that topic would ideally be gathered into one paragraph/section; repeating ideas rather than progressing through focused points methodically; disorganized paragraphs that create a herky jerky sequence of material rather than a streamlined progression. Deviates from the prescribed structure.

Style

Your writing style should be authoritative, concise, precise, and academic. These are your goals:

  • Consistent, precise, concise
  • Varied sentence structures and word choices
  • Integrate quoted material in three ways: tagged, blended, and colon, all with proper punctuation and capitalization
  • Adheres to the conventions of grammar, mechanics, usage, and spelling for American English

RUBRIC: Style

Excellent: Includes a wide variety of sentence structures and word choices to create a tonally consistent and rhetorically effective voice while maintaining superb clarity; note that perfect grammar isnt necessary for all genres and audiencesinstead, the goal is to use language carefully to create desired rhetorical effects within a particular context.  

Possible issues: Style may not fit the genre or audience; repetitive choices regarding sentence structures; misused words; stylistic choices that may compromise the rhetorical integrity of the work, such as offensive language; issues with grammar and mechanics that disrupt reader experience and detract from the rhetorical effectiveness of the writing; inconsistency.

Design & MLA

  • Your final draft should meet the guidelines of the most recent MLA handbook, including page formatting and citations. See this sample paper for guidance.

RUBRIC: Design

Excellent: All material presented with proper formattingsee MLA 9th edition guidelines, using Purdue OWL as a resourceand in an orderly layout with clear labels, headings, and so on as needed for optimized reader navigation.

Possible issues: Lacks adherence to MLA standards; jumbled elements and/or unlabeled elements where labels are needed for clarity and navigability; sloppy presentation.

Final Draft Submission

Submit only your final draft to this assignment on Canvas. The essay should have no residual comments from workshops or footnotes from your meta draft.

courses.syllabus:
ENGL1105: First-year Writing I : Introduction to College Composition

Instructor: Rob Hooper
Email: hoop@vt.edu
Office: Shanks 340D 
Office Hours: Tuesdays & Wednesdays, 3PM-4PM, and by appointment

Course Description

Introduction to rhetorical analysis, visual rhetoric, critical writing, and critical thinking; intensive reading of works in multiple genres; practice in writing and revision; fundamentals of oral presentations.

Course Overview

Welcome to ENGL1105! This semester you will gain grounded, practical experience with the conventions of academic discourse. The subject of the course is writing: how effective writers write in all variety of situations, in and beyond college; what successful writing looks like; and how specific practices, strategies, and concepts will aid you in becoming a more flexible, adaptive, and skillful communicator.

The course is structured around three projects. For each project, we'll emphasize rhetorical concepts and the writing process, which means you will spend considerable time drafting, workshopping, revising, and discussing rhetoric, writing, and related concepts with your peers and your instructor. Instructions for each assignment will be available on Canvas and provided in class, and you'll receive guidance through class discussion and feedback throughout each project.

Ultimately, by reading critically and writing consistentlywith feedback from me and your peersyou will develop skills that will serve you well in college and beyond. After completing English 1105, you should be able to successfully meet the outcomes below.

ENGL1105 Outcomes

Principles + 1105 Outcomes Description
Rhetorical knowledge You will have practiced using language consciously and identifying rhetorical qualities in composing situations. 
Writing processes You will have engaged in invention, drafting, and rewriting, providing explicit evidence of a writing process.
Genre conventions You will have demonstrated awareness of academic writing genre conventions, including mechanics and syntax.
Multimodal transformation You will have adapted your writing to distinct rhetorical contexts, drawing attention to the way composition transforms across contexts and forms (e.g., visual, oral, and digital).
Reflective practice You will have applied feedback from instructor, peers, and individual reflection to rethink, re-see, and ultimately revise your work.

Course Texts and Materials

Pick which version of the textbook you want:

Hard copy: Everyone's An Author (Virginia Tech Custom)

Digital copy: Virginia Tech Everyone's An Author, Fourth Edition

Both versions are available from the Virginia Tech Bookstore. Supplemental readings will be made available through Canvas. 

Feedback

You will receive many different kinds of feedback on your writing during this course. Some responses will come from fellow students and some will come from your instructor. All forms of feedback, including responses you receive from scheduling individual or group appointments in the Writing Center, are important; they tell you in various ways how your readers are responding to your writing. This will also help you learn how to assess your own work.

Grading

Grading in the course is focused on three major projects and a collection of daily assignments categorized as "Prep & Practice" (P&P). 

The major projects are graded holistically, which means that the overall quality of a final draft is evaluated within the context of the project as a whole. 

Here are the major assignment categories and the percentage of the course grade each project accounts for:

  • Prep & Practice - 70%
  • Argument - 10%
  • Analysis - 10%
  • Narrative - 10%

Each of the projects will be described fully in separate prompts that I will circulate at an appropriate time in the semester. All grades will be posted in the Canvas grade book associated with this course. You must complete all major projects to be eligible for a passing grade in ENGL 1105. 

Turning in Work

  • To keep our schedule, everybody needs to turn in work on time. Therefore, no late work will receive credit.
  • Keep a personal copy of your work for all assignments. That way, you have a backup copy if something goes wrong with Canvas, etc.
  • Each assignment will have instructions for submission. Generally, you'll submit documents to me through Canvas or exchange Google documents in designated folders.
  • Please name all of your files using this format:
    • LastName, FirstName - DueDate - Assignment Name

Additional Policies and Guidelines

Struggling in Class

If for any reason you feel you are struggling this semester, I hope that you will feel comfortable letting me know as soon as possible. This includes anything that might affect whether or not you can participate to the best of your abilityincluding physical injury, medical illness, mental health, depression or anxiety, relationship abuse or violence, grief or unmanageable stress. I am not a trained counselor but can put you in touch with resources on campus to support you in whatever ways you wish.

If you know, think, or are concerned that you have a disability (temporary or permanent) that will affect your active participation in this course, I hope that you will feel comfortable letting me know privately as soon as possible so that we may arrange accommodations or get resources from the Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD) office.

Attendance and Participation

Excessive tardiness or absence will affect a student's course grade, and students are expected to be present and prepared for the duration of each class meeting. Attendance is required for credit on all in-class work, which constitutes more than half of the course grade. Arriving late or leaving early will likely result in the loss of credit on a portion of that day's coursework. For example, if we begin a class with a peer workshop, a tardy student will not receive credit for the workshop but can earn credit on subsequent work, such as participating in a discussion or writing a journal entry.

Additionally, all work will be evaluated for credit within the context of in-class course content, such as discussions, lectures, and oral instructions; therefore, earning full credit on all assignments requires attendance directly and/or indirectly. 

ENGL1105 is a course in language learning, and language is learned in communities, usually by social interactions; therefore, it is essential that you visit this course shell  often  and participate in a manner respectful of the varied dispositions and worldviews among us. Participation, willing involvement, and earnest, timely engagement with the activities of the class will be factored into your overall grade in association with the writing due at any point. Extended periods of time without checking in  and lack of preparation for class will affect your classmates' work as well as your own. The work you do in and in preparation for class is vital to our weekly modules. In addition, our syllabus and schedule are only a projection and may be subject to changes and revisions as it seems appropriate, necessary, or just interesting. 

Students enrolled in English Department classes are expected to participate in interactive activities. They will, for example, routinely discuss reading assignments, write  on impromptu topics, participate in collaborative activities, or engage in peer review of drafts. Students who miss these activities regularly cannot reasonably make them up. As a result, students who do not participate regularly should expect to receive lower grades in the course, and students who miss more than the equivalent of two weeks of class should consider withdrawing and taking the class in a future semester. I do not anticipate any of you will be in that position, however, and I would greatly prefer to see everyone become invested in the coursework, learn a lot, and make ENGL1105 a meaningful experience.

Computer and Internet Usage

We will be interacting with a variety of sites on the internet during the course. Please let me know right away if you have not had any experience using a browser such as Firefox, Chrome, or Safari. When using a computer, save your work frequently, always make backup copies, and plan your projects with extra time allowed for unexpected challenges.

Much of the work you do for this class will be typewritten, using Google Docs. When turning in documents like this, please use an easily readable typeface, such as Times New Roman 12. Assign one inch margins and adhere to the page layout and documentation conventions established by MLA. Whatever the format of the assignment, I strongly urge you to plan ahead, to familiarize yourself with file formats and with the submission process, and to approach me with questions about submissions well in advance of the due dates. 

Communication with Peers; Communication with the Instructor

While you can expect a fair amount of leadership and direction to come from me, you should also make arrangements early in the semester to communicate with your peers. In other words, you are strongly encouraged to identify one or two (perhaps more) peers in the class with whom you can discuss readings and assignments, work through questions brought up in the class, and approach when you find something unclear. In short, my hope is that we all will prefer a climate in which dialogue and interaction runs between the instructor and students and also between and among students when questions come up. Finally, you should always be proactive about asking questions when you have them, either by raising questions in the Office area, in designated Discussions, or by contacting me or one of your peers privately. 

Email

To communicate by email we will use our vt.edu accounts, accessible via . It is most effective to use email to contact me about your work in the course. You can also set up an appointment to meet with me during my regular weekly office hours, to discuss your work, to ask questions, or to support you as you work toward your goals this semester. With rare exceptions, I will respond to all email inquiries within 48 hours.

Course Concerns

If you have questions or concerns about your progress in this course, please contact me for an appointment during office hours or email me to set up an appointment at another time. If you are not satisfied with our discussion, you may see the Director of Composition or the English Department Chair in the English Department in Shanks 323.

Artificial Intelligence

The purpose of this course is to provide opportunities for you to strengthen your own writing and communication skills, and delegating work associated with those skills to artificial intelligence (AI) directly interferes with the objectives of the course. Therefore, all of the work you submit for credit in this class should be your own, completed without inappropriate use of AI. If you have an interest in using AI to complete any portion of the coursework for this class, please discuss options with me before submitting work to avoid loss of credit or issues with academic integrity.

Services for You

Dean of Students

The office of the Dean of Students is committed to your overall well-being at Virginia Tech, related to a wide variety of issues, including personal or family hardship, instances of bias or discrimination, extended absences, and any other matters in which you need support and advocacy. The office assists students with adherence to policy, conflict resolution and prevention in resolving both academic and non-academic matters, providing an informal and neutral place for students to come to express any concerns. If you notice that one of your peers is struggling somehow but youre not sure how to handle it, consider contacting the Dean of Students for suggestions. The Dean of Students helps students resolve concerns, problems, or conflicts so as to assure the best possible university experience for everyone.

Campus Address  109 East Eggleston Hall
Phone Number      540-231-3787, 8-5 p.m., Mon.-Fri.
After Hours Phone 540-231-6411, press 1
Website                  https://www.dos.vt.edu/
Email                      dean.students@vt.edu

Writing Center

The Writing Center (Newman Library 2nd floor, Learning Commons; writingcenter@vt.edu, (540) 231-5436) offers one-to-one consulting for both undergraduate and graduate students. Please visit the Writing Center website to learn more about available formats for consultation sessions and for further details about scheduling appointments.

Principles of Community

This course adheres to Virginia Tech's Principles of Community. If you have any questions, please speak with me or consult the Principles of Community website at https://www.inclusive.vt.edu/Programs/vtpoc0.html.  

VT Womens Center

The Virginia Tech Womens Center (Yellow House at 206 Washington Street; 540-231-7806) works to foster a campus community where every person is supported and feels safe. Their counselors and advocates support students through all types of trauma including but not limited to sexual assault and other types of interpersonal violence and host many different types of programming and events to support the campus community. Follow them on Twitter and Instagram @womenscentervt.

LGBTQ+ Resource Center

The LGBTQ+ Resource Center (227 Squires Student Center) works to strengthen and sustain an open, supportive campus community at Virginia Tech. It offers a space where LGBTQ+ and all students can come together to work across our differences via education, information, and advocacy. All students are welcome in this space where you can be yourself and support diversity, equity, and inclusion. 

Office of Veterans Services

The Office of Veterans Services (130 Student Services Building; 540-231-5815) collaborates with other student services on campus to provide academic and personal support, tailored to address the unique needs of Virginia Tech veterans, including building a resume, navigating through the VA Healthcare system, and identifying education benefits. The staff are committed to helping military and veteran students, their spouses, and their dependents achieve their educational goals.

Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD)

Virginia Tech welcomes students with disabilities into the Universitys educational programs. The University promotes efforts to provide equal access and a culture of inclusion without altering the essential elements of coursework. If you anticipate or experience academic barriers that may be due to disability, including but not limited to ADHD, chronic or temporary medical conditions, deaf or hard of hearing, learning disability, mental health, or vision impairment, please contact the Services for Students with Disabilities (SSD) office (540-231-3788, ssd@vt.edu, or visit www.ssd.vt.edu). If you have an SSD accommodation letter, please meet with me privately during office hours as early in the semester as possible to deliver your letter and discuss your accommodations. You must give me reasonable notice to implement your accommodations, which is generally 5 business days and 10 business days for final exams.

Counseling and Psychological Services

The Cook Counseling Center (2475 Oak Lane, 540-231-6557) is dedicated to addressing the mental health needs of Virginia Tech students, providing individual counseling, group counseling, and psychiatric services. Learn more about their services online at https://www.ucc.vt.edu/.

University Policies

Policy on Harassment, Discrimination, and Sexual Assault

Virginia Tech is committed to supporting students and upholding the Universitys Policy on Harassment, Discrimination, and Sexual Assault. Under Title IX, discrimination on the basis of sex is prohibited. If you experience an incident of sex discrimination (such as sexual assault, sex- or gender-based harassment, intimate-partner violence or stalking), we encourage you to report it. You may obtain confidential support from the Title IX Coordinator Katie Polidoro (polidoro@vt.edu; 540-231-1824). As Virginia Tech faculty member, I serve as a Title IX Responsible Employee and thus must report any incidents of sexual misconduct and interpersonal violence involving Virginia Tech students, faculty and staff to the Title IX Coordinator regardless of whether the incident occurs on or off campus. 

If you wish to discuss an incident confidentially without notifying the Title IX Coordinator, you may contact the Cook Counseling Center (2475 Oak Lane, 540-231-6557). For more information, see the Sexual Misconduct and Interpersonal Violence Policy at https://policies.vt.edu/1025.pdf, or visit the Title IX Coordinator site to request assistance at https://oea.vt.edu/about/requesting-assistance.html.

Honor Code and Plagiarism

The Undergraduate Honor Code pledge that each member of the university community agrees to abide by states:

As a Hokie, I will conduct myself with honor and integrity at all times.  I will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor will I accept the actions of those who do.

Students enrolled in this course are responsible for abiding by the Honor Code. A student who has doubts about how the Honor Code applies to any assignment is responsible for obtaining specific guidance from the course instructor before submitting the assignment for evaluation. Students are strongly discouraged from misusing sites such as Chegg and CourseHero, as well as misusing ChatGPT and other Generative Artificial Intelligence. Students are strongly encouraged to consult their faculty members regarding the use of such outside materials as the misuse of these sources may constitute a violation of the Honor Code. Ignorance of the rules does not exclude any member of the University community from the requirements and expectations of the Honor Code.

For additional information about the Honor Code, please visit: https://www.honorsystem.vt.edu/

-END-

courses.name: Intro Computer Organization I

assignments.name: Homework 1
assignments.description:
Homework 1: Setting Up and Using Directories

In this assignment, you will be creating and working within a directory structure that you will create in your container. You will be writing out the commands you used to accomplish each step along the way that you will then submit to Canvas in a file named homework1.txt. We will use this file to run your commands to see if they are correct.

You will submit: 1. a plaintext file named homework1.txt

To ensure a plaintext file, you should see this if you run file homework1.txt:

  • homework1.txt: ASCII text

Note that RTF (rich text format) is native on Macs and is not plaintext.

Setup

You will be creating a file structure from scratch in your container. It will be based around organizing a grocery store. You may use any Linux terminal you wish, including the one in VSCode. However, you MUST run the commands on terminal to produce the desired results, do not use the UI in VSCode.

For example, if I asked you to list the contents of the current directory, your command would look something like this:

ls

ls is the command that will list the current contents of a directory.

Before we start with the questions, make sure you are in your dev container. If you are using VSCode, you should be automatically connected. This assumes you have already set up the connection.

Once you are connected, in the terminal in VSCode, it should say something like: root@####### directory where is there some combination of letters and numbers after the root@ and the directory is going to be where you setup your container. We have recommended cs2505.

 

Questions

On the first line of your file, put the path to the interpreter:

#! /bin/bash

# My commands come after this comment.

For each of the following steps, in your homework1.txt file put the # symbol and then the step on a line, e.g. #1, then on the next line or lines put the command you would type to make the step happen. To make it easier to read, put a blank line after each set of commands and the next step. E.G:

#1
ls

#2
cd home

#3
rm *

  1. At the top of the file (after #! /bin/bash), put a # followed by your name and then after you name put your VT PID. Your PID is not your 9-0 number. The PID is the first part of your email address. On the line after that, put another # and then the pledge. As a Hokie, I will conduct myself with honor and integrity at all times. I will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor will I accept the actions of those who do. For organizational purposes, you may want to make a directory called homework1 to hold the file structure you will be creating. Then move into that directory.

  2. We are designing the inventory system for a grocery store. Lets make a folder called aisles that will contain the contents of each aisle. How will you make a folder called aisles?

  3. Great! We have a place to put our inventory items. Move into the aisles directory.

  4. We are now inside the aisles directory. Make 3 more folders: produce and seasonal and snacks. You may use 1 or multiple commands. Now you have a hierarchy of folders where produce, seasonal, and snacks are 3 subfolders inside of aisles. 

  5. Move into the snacks directory.

  6. Make three new files: chips.txt, cookies.txt, and peanuts.txt

  7. Show the contents of the snacks directory.

  8. Move back up a level into the aisles directory and down into the produce directory. Use 1 or multiple commands but make sure you show all your steps. For this question, use a relative path, not an absolute path.

  9. Inside the produce directory, create 2 more folders: fruits and vegetables.

  10. Without leaving the produce directory, add lemon.txt and pumpkin.txt to fruits.

  11. Move into the vegetables directory. Add 3 files: potato.txt, spinach.txt, and tomato.txt.

  12. Wait, a tomato is technically a fruit! Without leaving the vegetables directory, move tomato.txt to the fruits directory.

  13. Navigate to the seasonal directory. Use 1 or multiple commands but make sure you show all your steps.

  14. Since Halloween is coming up, add spooky_decorations.txt and costumes.txt to seasonal.

  15. Without leaving the seasonal directory, move pumpkin.txt into the seasonal directory.

  16. As the year goes on, the seasonal aisle will change. Lets set up for winter. Rename spooky_decorations.txt to festive_decorations.txt and pumpkin.txt to candy_cane.txt.

  17. Remove costumes.txt from the seasonal aisle.

 

Helpful Ideas

This might be your first time doing this and you might not be sure how to do some of these steps. Thats okay. What I suggest you do is in VS Code on the terminal, figure out what command will do the step. You can create this file structure within VS Code as you work if it will help you figure out the correct commands.

For example, if the step ask you to move into a directory, make sure you can do that, then put that in your answer.

All of the steps are meant to be done in order, like a recipe. You do one step and then do the next. So as you are doing the steps you are moving around in the file tree you are making. If you get lost use pwd to figure out where you are in the tree. It will tell you what folder you are in. It stands for print working directory.

Some of these steps have more than one way to do them. Some of them might require more than one command and others can be accomplished using a single command but multiple arguments. Both are acceptable. However, some of the commands require that you stay in a certain directory. Pay attention to those; we will go through and grade those for correctness and following directions.

Grading

After we run your file, we are going to use the tree command to see if your commands create the correct file tree.

If you want to do this then once you have your solution, you can run it like this (which invokes the bash shell interpreter to run your file):

bash homework1.txt

OR (this one uses the interpreter that you put at the top of your file)

./homework1.txt

It will do each command and make the directories and files as you told it to.

To see the tree, you can run the tree command and it will create the tree.

This is what it should look like

aisles/
 produce
    fruits
       lemon.txt
       tomato.txt
    vegetables
        potato.txt
        spinach.txt
 seasonal
    candy_cane.txt
    festive_decorations.txt
 snacks
     chips.txt
     cookies.txt
     peanuts.txt

5 directories, 9 files

Submission

Upload your homework1.txt for grading. (PS: Don't worry if Canvas changes the name of your file after multiple submissions. It should still work correctly.)

We reserve the right to review your answers to ensure you have an appropriate set of commands for each step.

Requirements

  1. This is an individual assignment.
  2. You must create the directory structure by following the steps above. You may NOT just create the final tree structure.
  3. You may not use generative AI.
  4. You may not intentionally attempt to modify the intended running of the autograder.

Points

This is worth 100 points. You may lose points if it is determined that you did not do the step as specified (e.g. left the directory when told to stay in the same one).

The autograder will award up to 85 points. The remaining 15 points will come from making sure you followed the directions in each step (the TAs will grade this after the assignment deadline has passed). You may see a harsher deduction if you only build the final tree structure without actually following the steps.

assignments.name: Homework 2
assignments.description:
HW2: Vectors and Writing Functions in C

Instructions:

In this C programming homework, you will be writing a single C file called vector.c containing several vector functions. You will be provided with a main.c and a vector.h file.

Since we are providing the main.c and the vector.h files, any changes you make to them on your computer will not be reflected in the code you submit to Canvas. For your code to work correctly, you must work with the main.c and vector.h files as provided. Download the files and put them in the folder where you would like to work within your Docker instance (on level with or in a subdirectory of where you put your Dockerfile).

main.c

vector.h

sample_files.tar

Download vector.h

Honor Code

This is an individual assignment. All code should be written on your own. No one should see your code except for you and members of the course staff. We will be checking for violations.

What to Submit:

  • a single C file called vector.c submitted to this Canvas assignment
  • NOTE: if you make multiple submissions, Canvas will rename the file to something like vector (1).c
    • we will handle renaming the file in our autograder, so do not worry about Canvas changing the file name

 

Functions:

These function headers will also be in the vector.h file. They cannot be modified since you are not allowed to modify the vector.h file.

The dot_product function should compute the dot product between two vectors of varying lengths. (You may assume the lengths are the same.)

@param vec1 The array representing the coordinates of vector 1
@param vec2 The array representing the coordinates of vector 2
@param arr_len The length of the arrays (AKA the number of elements in the array)
@return The dot product of the vectors

double dot_product(const double vec1[], const double vec2[], int arr_len);

The angle_between function should calculate the angle between two vectors in degrees. (You may assume the lengths are the same.)

@param vec1 The array representing the coordinates of vector 1
@param vec2 The array representing the coordinates of vector 2
@param arr_len The length of the arrays (AKA the number of elements in the array)
@return The angle between the vectors in degrees

double angle_between(const double vec1[], const double vec2[], int arr_len);

The subtract function should subtract two vectors (v1 - v2) and store the results into the new vector.

@param v1_dir The direction of the first vector, given in degrees
@param v1_mag The magnitude of the first vector 
@param v2_dir The direction of the second vector, given in degrees
@param v2_mag The magnitude of the second vector 
@param new_dir The storage location for the calculated direction of the subtracted vectors (give between 0-360 degrees)
@param new_mag The storage location for the calculated magnitude of the subtracted vectors 

void subtract(double v1_dir, double v1_mag, double v2_dir, double v2_mag, double* new_dir, double* new_mag);

For more information on how to do these vector operations, check out these links:

https://mathinsight.org/dot_productLinks to an external site. (Dot product)

https://byjus.com/angle-between-two-vectors-formula/Links to an external site. (Angle between two vectors)

https://courses.lumenlearning.com/suny-physics/chapter/test-vector-addition-and-subtraction-analytical-methods/Links to an external site. (Vector subtraction)

 

Input Files and Output Files

Here is an example of what an input file will look like:

dot <1.423, 92.31, 37.18> <827.22, 78.6, 2.33>
angle <17.32, 98.492> <73.59, 1.327>
subtract 38.9 8.0 129.215 2.129

The cooresponding output file looks like this:

Command: dot_product
        <1.423, 92.310, 37.180>
        <827.220, 78.600, 2.330>
        The dot product of the two vectors is 8519.329

Command: angle_between
        <17.320, 98.492>
        <73.590, 1.327>
        The angle between the two vectors is 78.993 degrees

Command: subtract
        V1 Direction: 38.900     V1 Magnitude: 8.000
        V2 Direction: 129.215    V2 Magnitude: 2.129
        The resultant vector has a direction of 24.019 degrees and a magnitude of 8.290

Note that you do not need to read in any information from the input file, nor do you need to do any printing to the output file; the main handles that for you. Your job is simply to make sure your functions produce the correct values so that main displays the correct text.

 

How To Compile and Run

You will need to use the command line to compile and run your C code, just like we have been doing in class. You may choose any name you like for your executable, but we will provide an example here. The main provided takes 2 arguments to run: an input file and an output file. The input files will be given to you and you may give the output files any name you want; again, we will provide an example.

Compile

gcc -o hw2_vector -Wall -Wextra -g -lm main.c vector.c

You may notice the addition of the -lm option which we have not used in class. The -lm option enables the use of the math.h library, which we will need for this assignment. Make sure you include it in your compile line. Note that it is a lowercase L, not a number one. Resolve any errors and warnings, then move on to running your code.

The math library also includes a constant you will want to use: M_PI. M_PI is an approximation (albeit a close one) of pi (3.1415.....). If you installed the C Extensions that VS Code recommends (which we do NOT recommend you install), it will likely highlight M_PI as an error. Compile it anyway; it's not an error.

Running

To run your code, you will need to provide the name of the executable, the name of the input file you want to test on, and the name of the output file to use. WARNING: If you provide a file that has something you want in it as the name of the output file, it will be overwritten. Be careful.

./hw2_vector input-dot.txt my_output_dot.txt

is an example of how you might test with the first input file. Extend this running command to the rest of your input files.

Please note: The name of the input file must match the name of a file in your current working directory. Otherwise, you will get a segfault due to an invalid file pointer being created in the main method. You can name your input files whatever you want, but you will need to change the command accordingly.

Testing (Don't Worry; Not Unit Testing)

Once you have run your code, you probably want to see if you are getting the correct answers. To do this, you can compare the results in the output file you generated to the results in the provided output files (AKA the results from the instructor source code). You can do this using the diff command on the terminal.

diff -yw my_output_dot.txt prof-output-dot.txt

The -y option means compare side-by-side. The -w option means that any amount of whitespace is comparable; so if you have 3 spaces and we have 17, those are considered equivalent.

If you would rather have the difference in a file, consider using the redirection operator to dump the results into a file:

diff -yw my_output_dot.txt prof-output-dot.txt >> diff_dot.txt

Here are some more sample input and output files you can use for your own testing: sample_files.tar (same files as the top of the page). To open the .tar file, use the tar command.

tar -xvf sample_files.tar

The -x option extracts files from the .tar file. The -v option means all files that are extracted are listed. The -f option means you are reading from an archive file.

Download sample_files.tar

Please note: Both of the output files you are comparing must exist in your current working directory. Otherwise, your diff command will be comparing a file to a blank file.

Grading

You may submit this assignment up to 10 times; this limit is not intended to be a barrier to you getting the score you want, but it is intended to make sure you are testing your code before you make a submission. Do not use the grader as a guess-and-check method. Use the sample files you are given along with the diff command to check that your code is performing as expected before you make a submission.

If you run out of submissions, just ask. We will be able to see if it looks like you were testing your code between attempts. If you don't understand how to test your code, ask a TA or on Piazza. The Testing section above should explain it, but if you need more help, let us know! This type of file comparison is not going away in this course.

 

The grader will run this same type of comparison. You should have a good idea of how you will score on the assignment before you ever make a submission.

You may also submit using the late submission policy for 15% off per day late OR you may submit a no-questions-asked extension request from the Canvas homepage.

 

The autograder runs every 15 minutes to give you a results file, which will include your score. The autograder runs on the hour and every quarter-hour after (ex. 9:00, 9:15, 9:30, 9:45, etc.)

The maximum score from the autograder is a 90. The remaining 10 points will come from commenting your code and breaking the problem up into reasonable steps.

 

When you submit, the grader will run 5 times on 5 different test files. When you get your results file back, the tests will be one after another. The score at the top of the file is only the score for that one test, not your actual score. Scroll through all of the tests to see your scores on the different tests.

assignments.name: Homework 3
assignments.description:
• Homework 3
    • Struct
    • Functions
    • Commands
    • Files
    • Requirements
    • Grading
    • Suggestions

Homework 3

In this homework, you will be creating a struct to represent a Java-style array.

Struct

struct Array
{
    int values[SIZE];
    int count;
};

The struct you will be working with contains 3 pieces of information:

  • data: the array of ints
  • count: the current number of elements in the array
  • SIZE: the total number of elements that could fit into the array
    • this is a constant that will be declared prior to the struct definition in the same header file

This is an example input file:

add 10
add 11 1
add 12 0
find 10
find 11
find 12
find 13
contains 10
contains 100
display all
removeAt 1
display data
removeAt 100
clear
display data

That input file should produce this output file:

Command: add 10
    10 successfully added
Command: add 11 1
    11 successfully added
Command: add 12 0
    12 successfully added
Command: find 10
    10 found at index 1
Command: find 11
    11 found at index 2
Command: find 12
    12 found at index 0
Command: find 13
    13 not found in array
Command: contains 10
    10 contained in array
Command: contains 100
    100 not contained in array
Command: display all
    12, 10, 11, 0, 0, 0, 0
    SIZE of array: 7
Command: removeAt 1
    data removed from array at index 1
Command: display data
    12, 11
    Count of elements in array: 2
Command: removeAt 100
    data not removed array at index 100
Command: clear 
Command: display data
    Count of elements in array: 0

Functions

void initialize( struct Array* data );

This function will set every array index to the value 0 and sets the count of the data to 0.

bool add( struct Array* data, int element )

This function takes a pointer to an Array struct and a number as an element. The element should be placed at the next available position in the Array struct. If the array has no more available indices, then false is returned from the function. Otherwise, return true.

bool addAt( struct Array* data, int element, int index )

This function takes a pointer to an Array struct, a number as an element, and an index. The element should be placed at the given index in the Array. Return true if the addition was successful.

If the given index is 0 or less than 0, add data to the beginning of the array. If index is count or greater than count, add data to the end of the array. Otherwise, make a space in the array and store the data at the given index. Any data that was at the given index and in index positions greater than the given one, are moved up one index position. If the array has no more available indices, then false is returned from the function. Otherwise, return true.

int find( struct Array data, int element )

This function takes an Array struct (not a pointer) and a number as an element. If the element exists in the Array, return the first index where the element appears. If the element does not appear in the Array, return -1.

bool contains( struct Array data, int element )

This function takes an Array struct (not a pointer) and a number as an element. If the element is in the Array, return true; otherwise, return false.

bool removeAt( struct Array* data, int index)

This function takes a pointer to an Array struct and an index value. The element at position index should be removed and all elements followed it should be moved to a lower index in the Array by one. If the item at the index is successfully removed, return true; otherwise, return false.

void display( struct Array data, FILE* out, bool all )

This function takes an Array struct and a file pointer. Output the data in the given array to the output file in a comma separated list of values.

If all is true, then every element in the array is displayed, including any that may not have values. Also a message about the size of the array is given on the next line

If all is false, then you only display the elements that have been set. Also, on the next line, a message about how many elements are in the array is output.

See the example output for details on the second line of output.

void clear( struct Array* data)

This function takes a pointer to an Array struct. All elements should be reset to 0.

Commands

Compile:

gcc -Wall -Wextra -std=c11 -g -o array_struct array.c main.c

Run:

./array_struct name_of_input_file name_of_output_file

Diff example:

./array_struct input-1.txt my-output-1.txt

diff -wy my-output-1.txt prof-output-1.txt

We have also included a Makefile for you to use. You can run any of the targets you wish, but just typing make will run the all target and compile your code. Run other targets with make target_name.

Files 

  • main.c
  • array.h
  • Makefile
  • example.txt - output.txt

Even more samples to test with:

  • examples.zip

You will submit your array.c file only.

Requirements

  1. NO GLOBAL VARIABLES. We reserve the right to assign a 0 if you use global variables. Global constants are ok.
  2. You must write all of the functions given above. These functions should perform similarly to the methods in the Java.util.ArrayList class. The functions behaviors should be contained in their individual functions (e.g. add should actually modify the structs data, not just do the printing expected of the add function).
  3. You must comment your code. Include the Honor Code: As a Hokie, I will conduct myself with honor and integrity at all times. I will not lie, cheat, or steal, nor will I accept the actions of those who do.
  4. Your code must compile with the given main.c and array.h files.
  5. You may not write code in the H file; you must write your code in a C file. You may declare your functions.

Grading

You will submit your array.c file to Canvas. You will be limited to 10 submissions. Feedback will be given in Canvas. Please make sure to check your feedback. Ask questions if you are unsure of what the feedback is saying.

You will earn at most 90 points from the grader. The remaining 10 points will be awarded after the assignment is done by the TAs.

Suggestions

We encourage you to write helper methods (declared as static) in your C file. Consider these situations:

  1. You need to be able to shift elements back down the array when you remove an item.
  2. You need to be able to push elements up the array when adding to a specific index.
  3. You need to be able to increase the size of the array (make a hole).

Note that you are not required to write these functions. Only those functions listed in the H file are required. However, we suggest that you think about your solution in terms of single units of work. If you are going to be repeating the same behavior multiple times, consider making it a method.

Remember that you are responsible for updating count in your struct. C will not do it for you. Make sure you are updating them appropriately.
