Managing a Roster of Names in C

Dynamic Strings, Freeing Memory, and Input File Commands

In this assignment, you will manage student enrollment for a course with set of commands. You will read the commands from an input file that is passed to you as an argument on the command line. Please make sure you look at the restrictions BEFORE you write your code.

Sample Input/Output

The sample input and output files will also be available for download for your use.

Here is a sample input file:

5
add Allyson Senger
modify David McPherson:Dave McPherson
add Steve Edwards
display
remove Allyson Senger
remove Siwei Cao
delete
2
add Margaret Ellis
add Allyson Senger
add Heath Hillman
modify Allyson Senger:Allyson Lauren
display 
delete
0

The first line of the file will be the maximum enrollment of the class. This is handled in main. Take a look to see how it was pulled out and used to create an array of Strings representing a roster of students.

Each subsequent line will contain a single command. You must implement at least 1 function per command in a roster.c file.

The main file has a loop to go through all of the commands and call your function for each command. It does not do any of the work for the command; that is your job. The functions you write must fully implement the command.

Here is the corresponding output file:

Command: add Allyson Senger
    Allyson Senger was added. 4 spot(s) remain.
Command: modify David McPherson:Dave McPherson
    No student with name David McPherson found.
Command: add Steve Edwards
    Steve Edwards was added. 3 spot(s) remain.
Command: display
    Currently Enrolled:
        Student 1: Allyson Senger
        Student 2: Steve Edwards
Command: remove Allyson Senger
    Student Allyson Senger removed. The course now has 4 seats remaining.
Command: remove Siwei Cao
    No student named Siwei Cao was found to remove.
Command: delete
    Steve Edwards removed in class delete.
    Class was restarted and reopened for enrollment.

Command: add Margaret Ellis
    Margaret Ellis was added. 1 spot(s) remain.
Command: add Allyson Senger
    Allyson Senger was added. 0 spot(s) remain.
Command: add Heath Hillman
    Student Heath Hillman not added. The class is already at capacity.
Command: modify Allyson Senger:Allyson Lauren
    Student Allyson Senger name modified to Allyson Lauren.
Command: display
    Currently Enrolled:
        Student 1: Margaret Ellis
        Student 2: Allyson Lauren
Command: delete
    Margaret Ellis removed in class delete.
    Allyson Lauren removed in class delete.
    Class was restarted and reopened for enrollment.

Functions

ADD

int add_student(FILE* input, FILE* output, char* students[], int current_students,
    int const max_students);

The add command will be called with a student name. The student should be added to the array representing the class roster if there are still spaces remaining in the course. It should return the number of students enrolled in the course after this student is added. The student should not be added if the course is at maximum capacity.

ex. add Allyson Senger

MODIFY

void modify_name(FILE* input, FILE* output, char* students[], int current_students);

The modify command will be called with 2 names, separated by a colon. Search the roster for the first name, and if it exists, replace it with the new name. Make sure you modify the memory required to store the new name (it could be shorter or longer).

ex. modify William Thomas:Will Thomas
ex. modify Alex Shull:Alexandria Shull

REMOVE

int remove_student(FILE* in, FILE* output, char* students[], int current_students,
    int const max_students);

The remove command should search the roster to see if the given student is enrolled in the course. If so, the student should be removed from the roster. The function should return the number of students enrolled in the course after the student is removed (or not if they never were enrolled in the first place).

If the student is removed, the space in the array where the student was needs to be covered up. We will accomplish this by moving all of the students that were at indices higher than the removed student down one location.

ex. remove Marina Meza

DISPLAY

void display_class(FILE* out, char* students[], int current_students);

The display command should output the students currently enrolled in the class as shown in the sample output file. You can use this function to help you test the others. For example, write an input file with an add command and a display command and make sure what you expect is displayed. The display function should be fairly trivial. It is more for your benefit.

ex. display

DELETE

void delete_class(FILE* out, char* students[], int* current_students);

The delete command should remove all students from the class. Think about what you actually need to do in terms of memory to accomplish this. Do NOT use your remove function. The delete command will be followed by a number; this number represents the new size of the class, which is handled in main. You do not need to worry about reading past this number or doing anything with it.

Your job in this function is to make sure that the memory that was allocated is freed.

ex. delete
23

Requirements

  1. You must write your functions in a file called roster.c, which you will submit to Canvas.
  2. You must write at least one function per command.
  3. You must have a clean valgrind report to receive full credit.
  4. You must comment your functions with descriptions of their purpose. You may use the descriptions from the assignment.
  5. You must comment any other parts of your code that are complex.
  6. You may not use any generative AI, like ChatAPI, on this assignment.
  7. You may not use global variables.
  8. This is an individual assignment.

Allowed Assumptions

  1. The input file will exist when we run your code.
  2. No name will be longer than 100 characters.
  3. No invalid commands will be given. However, invalid arguments to commands may be given.
  4. There is enough space on the system to create an output file.
  5. There is enough space on the system to allocate memory for the names.
  6. The last command will be a delete, followed by a number.
  7. You will not have duplicate names between 'delete' calls. 

Restrictions

  1. You may NOT use any of the following functions from string.h:
    • memchr, memcmp, memcpy (any of them), memmove (any of them), memset (any of them), strdup, or strndup

Grading

85 points will be awarded for code correctness. If your code runs 100% correctly on the grader, you will receive 85 points. The remaining 15 points will be awarded for a clean valgrind report.

Valgrind

https://canvas.vt.edu/courses/215700/pages/how-to-valgrind (page the TAs are working on to explain Valgrind)

Valgrind is a tool that allows us to check our code for memory leaks. You can read more about it here: https://valgrind.org/Links to an external site.

We run valgrind the same way we run other executables. We just happen to use a lot of options to run Valgrind, and we typically redirect the output into a text file to make it easier to refer to later. Here is the valgrind command we will be using to evaluate your code:

valgrind --leak-check=full --show-leak-kinds=all -s --log-file="valgrind_output.txt"
  ./<executable> <input_file> <output_file>

It is important that you use the options shown to make sure you see the same results that we will see. Valgrind will tell you things like if you have a open file pointer that was never closed. It will also tell you where you asked for a block of memory that you never got rid of so that you can trace that piece of memory through your code to eventually free it.

A clean Valgrind report looks like this:

==3844570== Memcheck, a memory error detector
==3844570== Copyright (C) 2002-2022, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al.
==3844570== Using Valgrind-3.21.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info
==3844570== Command: ./jrpg
==3844570==
==3844570==
==3844570== HEAP SUMMARY:
==3844570==     in use at exit: 0 bytes in 0 blocks
==3844570==   total heap usage: 1 allocs, 1 frees, 8,192 bytes allocated
==3844570==
==3844570== All heap blocks were freed -- no leaks are possible
==3844570==
==3844570== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0)

Note that the number of allocs and frees is the same, the amount in use at exit is 0 bytes in 0 blocks, and the error summary reports 0 errors from 0 contexts. This is what we expect to see for a clean Valgrind report.

This is an example of a write past the end of a memory block we requested (or in Java terms, an ArrayIndexOutOfBounds). It is saying that we are writing something that is size 4 bytes 0 bytes past the 40 bytes we had originally asked for.

  ==19182== Invalid write of size 4
  ==19182==    at 0x804838F: f (example.c:6)
  ==19182==    by 0x80483AB: main (example.c:11)
  ==19182==  Address 0x1BA45050 is 0 bytes after a block of size 40 alloc'd
  ==19182==    at 0x1B8FF5CD: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:130)
  ==19182==    by 0x8048385: f (example.c:5)
  ==19182==    by 0x80483AB: main (example.c:11)

 

This is an example of unreleased dynamic memory. The line numbers for functions f() and main() show you where this memory was CREATED, not where you are supposed to get rid of it. You should only get rid of the memory after you are done using it.

  ==19182== 40 bytes in 1 blocks are definitely lost in loss record 1 of 1
  ==19182==    at 0x1B8FF5CD: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:130)
  ==19182==    by 0x8048385: f (a.c:5)
  ==19182==    by 0x80483AB: main (a.c:11)

 

A conditional jump/move on uninitialized values means that an if statement or loop is relying on a value that may not have been defined to make a decision. You may have defined it at some point and then freed the memory associated with it or never initialized a field within a struct.

Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)
==25611==    at 0x108D1D: create_test (test.c:113)
==25611==    by 0x108C83: main (test.c:72)

 

Other errors you might see include unclosed file pointers (which will have fopen in the error) or invalid reads (which are the other side of ArrayIndexOutOfBounds where you try to access memory you did not ask for). 

If you run into an error you cannot diagnose, you are welcome to post Valgrind errors on Piazza or ask a TA. You may not post the associated code on Piazza, but we can help you interpret the error message.

 

Make sure these get fixed. Examples taken from https://valgrind.org/

Files

Here are some sample files.

  • main.c
  • roster.h
  • input.txt
  • output.txt
  • samples.zip

Homework 5 - Memory Manipulations

For this project we are going to be looking into how memory can be accessed and manipulated in C via pointers.

You will be given, among other inputs to your program, will be a data file in binary. This will be shown below.

00000000  15 8d 84 93 2f 5c 53 6b  06 6e 73 3d f1 ae 53 23  |..../\Sk.ns=..S#|

The above display is a created using a tool called hexdump. The left most column is the addresses in the output and the remaining columns are the data from the file, shown in hexadecimal. Of course, all files are in binary and some of those files use only ASCII data, but this file is just random bytes.

We will use this data to explore data. The rows of the data are in groups of 16 bytes, which is why if you look at the first column which is the starting address for the row, you see all 0s and the you see 1, then 2, and so on, since these are also displayed in hex.

The offset of a byte is the intersection of the row label and the column number. So the very first byte is at offset 0. The last byte in the first row is at offset 0xF. The first byte in the second row is 0x10. The last byte in the second row is in offset 0x1F. Remember each byte is represented as two hexadecimal numbers, and so each pair of hexadecimal numbers is a single byte. Finally so each group of 4 hexadecimal numbers is two bytes.

Another way of thinking about this is that we have an array of bytes, indexed just like the cells of any array, relative to the first byte in the memory block. If we called the array data, then data[1] would be 0x8d (or 14110) and data[21] would be 0x5c (or 9210).

Here is a C function that will display a selected block of bytes from such a memory block, using an array-based view of the necessary logic:

/** 
* Uses array-based logic to access a specified portion of a region of
* memory and print the corresponding bytes to a supplied file stream.
*/
void show_bytes(FILE* Out, const uint8_t base[], uint16_t
    index, uint8_t count )
{
    for (uint8_t pos = 0; pos < count; pos++)
    {
        fprintf(Out, "%02X", base[index + pos]);
    }
    fprintf(Out, "\n");
}

Suppose we executed the call: show_bytes(stdout, data, 34, 6)

Now, data[34] would be the byte 3a because 3410 is 0x22 and the function would print 6 bytes starting there, with two spaces separating the bytes: 3a a2 37 8e 0d 3e

(Remember, a hex nybble is a 4-bit value, so there are two nybbles, and hence two hex digits, per byte.)

Lets consider a few details in the implementation of that function:

  • We used const in specifying the second parameter. That means the function is not allowed to modify the contents of the array thats passed to it.
  • We refer to the bytes in the memory block using the type uint8_t; thats so we can avoid any issues that might arise if the high bit of a byte happened to be 1 (remember 2s complement representation).
  • The parameter index is of type uint16_t; that limits the size of the memory block. The maximum value of a uint16_t variable is 216 - 1 or 65535. Theres no good reason for that, really. It just gave me an excuse to add this to the discussion. A similar point could be made about the parameter count.
  • The format string "%02X" causes the variable to be displayed in two columns, with a leading 0 if necessary, in hexadecimal, and followed by two spaces.

The Functions

For this assignment, youll implement six C functions to perform different kinds of accesses to a block of memory. Be sure to pay attention to the restrictions that are imposed on your implementation. In particular, each function is restricted to using pointer notation to manage all accesses to the data;

Use of array bracket notation (ex. arr[3]) will result in a score of 0.

void show_bytes(FILE* out, const uint8_t* const base_address, uint16_t offset, 
    uint8_t how_many);

void show_value(FILE* out, const uint8_t* const base_address, uint32_t offset, 
    enum Sign sign, uint8_t number_of_bytes);

void find_byte(FILE* out, const uint8_t* const base_address, uint32_t length, 
    uint8_t byte);  

void find_sequence(FILE* out, const uint8_t* const base_address, 
    uint32_t length, const uint8_t* const sequence, uint32_t sequence_length);

void copy_block(uint8_t* const base_address, uint32_t source, 
    uint32_t destination, uint32_t length);

void blend_bytes(uint8_t* base_address, uint32_t first_offset, 
    uint32_t second_offset, uint32_t length);

show_bytes

The interface of the functions deserves a short discussion. The parameter, base_address, illustrates the use of const in two different ways. For a pointer used as a parameter, placing const before the pointer type means the function is not permitted to modify the value of the target of the pointer, and placing const after the pointer type means the function is not permitted to modify the value of the parameter (which would make it point to a different target).

In this case, we dont want this function to modify the contents of the memory block, the first use of const enforces that. And, we dont see any reason for the function to work with a pointer that has a different target than we have decided on, so the second use of const enforces that.

Its good practice to use const appropriately when designing function interfaces, especially when a parameter is a pointer.

Even so, you should also understand that the C language does make it possible for a programmer to create a local pointer, initialize it from the parameter, and use that local pointer in ways that violate the const restrictions you may have imposed. That doesnt make const useless, and a principled C programmer will avoid sidestepping const.

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte:

show_bytes(..., base_address, 23, 4): 83 3b 4a 54

show_bytes(..., base_address, 219, 2): f4 8b

show_bytes(..., base_address, 338, 12): 71 f1 5f 0c e7 83 fa 88 31 2b 1c eb

By the way, the parameters in the examples above are given in base 10; if you want to check the results against the hexdump, you may want to convert the offsets to hex as well. The first one would be 0x17.

We guarantee that testing will only be done with logically valid parameters.

The second function requires exploiting pointer typecasts in order to impose a specified interpretation on a segment of data in memory. You should be sure you review and understand the notes on that topic; reading the short tutorial at the end of this specification will help.

show_value

Consider the four bytes at the address 0xA2 in the hexdump: 92 35 6e 84

We could interpret those four bytes in a number of different, conflicting ways. They could be interpreted as four extended ASCII codes (using one of the many extensions of ASCII). They could be interpreted as a 32-bit floating-point number (a float in C or Java). They could be interpreted as a 32-bit signed integer or a 32-bit unsigned integer. Lets consider that in a bit more detail.

Numeric values are stored in little-endian order on x86 systems, so those four bytes will be interpreted as 0x846e3592 (2s complement representation), that yields the value -2073152110. As an unsigned integer (base-2 representation), that yields the value 2221815186.

We will also use an enumerated type to indicate to the function whether it should interpret the specified segment of data as a signed integer or an unsigned integer:

enum Sign {SIGNED, UNSIGNED};

Enumerated types (also available in Java) allow you to define a custom type whose values are descriptive labels, which can make your code much easier to understand.

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte:

show_value(..., base_address, 23, SIGNED, 1): -125

show_value(..., base_address, 148, UNSIGNED, 2): 15569

show_value(..., base_address, 148, SIGNED, 2): 15569

show_value(..., base_address, 243, UNSIGNED, 4): 3108945243 

show_value(..., base_address, 243,SIGNED, 4): -1186022053

find_byte

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte:

find_byte(..., base_address, 512, 0x7F): 37 58 6C 7F 147 1AA 1FF

find_byte(..., base_address, 512, 0): 6D 7A A0 111 17A 1Ac

find_byte(..., base_address, 512, 0xE9):

find_sequence

The fourth function requires searching the memory region for occurrences of a given sequence of bytes:

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte of the memory region. Each example shows a call, followed by before-and-after hexdump snapshots of the parts of the memory region that were used/affected by the call.

Looking for occurrences of: cd9ad8 60

copy_block

The fifth function requires copying a portion of the memory region to another location in the region:

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte of the memory region. Each example shows a call, followed by before-and-after hexdump snapshots of the parts of the memory region that were used/affected by the call.

copy_block(stdout, base_address, 0, 1, 1):

00000000 7F 10 22 EC 2B EA D1 F5  4E 92 62 B4 04 CB C3 34

changes to

00000000 7F 7F 22 EC 2B EA D1 F5  4E 92 62 B4 04 CB C3 34
copy_block(stdout, base_address, 0, 8, 8):

00000000 7F 7F 22 EC 2B EA D1 F5  4E 92 62 B4 04 CB C3 34

changes to

00000000 7F 7F 22 EC 2B EA D1 F5  7F 7F 22 EC 2B EA D1 F5
copy_block(stdout, base_address, 0xF8, 0x108, 8):

000000F0 B7 31 7A 8F B8 D6 AA BB  5D C7 AB AA 90 A8 D2 93
00000100 66 E9 06 81 F7 56 ED 27  1C 0C 0C 36 01 26 A5 B8

changes to

000000F0 B7 31 7A 8F B8 D6 AA BB  5D C7 AB AA 90 A8 D2 93
00000010 66 E9 06 81 F7 56 ED 27  5D C7 AB AA 90 A8 D2 93

When we test this function, we will restore the data block to its initial state, so that no earlier test changes the logical conditions of the test.

blend_bytes

The sixth function requires the bytes in a specific portion of a memory region, by blending them with bytes from another portion of the memory region:

Here are some example results, based on the memory block shown earlier, assuming *base_address is the first byte of the memory region. First, consider the following call:

blend_bytes(..., base_address + 0x1C0, data + 0x1D0, 8);

The two data blocks involved look like this before the call:

000001C0 17 48 8F 28 18 60 6F A9  56 F5 02 71 15 29 22 73

000001D0 15 18 50 6C B0 88 C8 1A  65 97 D8 53 FF C7 98 16

After the call, they should look like this:

00001C0 17 48 8F 28 18 60 6F A9  56 F5 02 71 15 29 22 73

00001D0 64 9C A8 EE 31 8E 3E 80  65 97 D8 53 FF C7 98 16

The way we are blending the bytes is as follows.

For each byte we are to blend:

  1. Take the nybbles from the first pointer and reverse them.
    • For example the byte 0x17 would become 0x71.
  2. Use the xor function on the corresponding byte from the second pointer
  3. Store the result where the second pointer is pointing.

So if we start with 0x17 and reverse the nybbles to get 0x71 then xor that with 0x15 the result is 0x64. Then we move to 0x48 and repeat. We stop when we have reached the count. In this example, the count is 8.

If you are looking for some guidance on the flipping, take a look at the file we wrote in class on November 4th. This isn't exactly the same, since we are flipping nybbles, but it is the idea of how to do this operation.

Getting Started

You should begin by downloading the posted C source files, main.c, pointer_functions.h

To compile the program, you should use the following command:

gcc -o pointer_functions -Wall -Wextra main.c pointer_functions.c

Use the samples that are posted to test. Like our last project, we will test each command individually and then all in one.

What to Submit

Submit your completed version of pointer_functions.c after testing.

Your submission will be compiled, tested and graded according to the formatting of your output and how many cases your solution handles correctly.

Test your program thoroughly with the supplied code before submitting it. If you do not get a perfect score, analyze the problem carefully and test your fix before submitting again.

Up to 80 points will be assigned for correctness. 20 points are reserved for a clean Valgrind report.

Pledge:

Each of your program submissions must be pledged to conform to the Honor Code requirements for this course.

Requirements:

  • You may not use array notation.
    • Using array notation will result in your grade being reduced to 0.
  • You may not #include <string.h>
  • You may not modify the main.c nor the pointer_functions.h.
    • We will supply those when you turn in your code.
  • We will be using the supplied Makefile to build your code.
    • Make sure your code will compile and run with this file.
  • No valgrind errors.

  • Comment your functions in the pointer_functions.c file.

Homework 6

For this assignment, you will have 6 (six) parts. Each one of the parts will work on translating x86-64 assembly to C code. In order to get full credit, you will have to submit each part. Each part will be scored independently of each part and your final grade will be the sum of each part. Each part is awarded points to compute to the total. You can see the value for each part below.

For each part, we will give you a C function that has been assembled. Your job is to translate it back to C. You will know you get it correct when you use the diff tool and there are no differences.

Your C file must be named partX.c where X is the part number (ex. part1.c, part4.c). Make sure you dont over write the correct assembly file when you assemble your code to test.

You can work on these in any order. You can submit them all at once, or one at a time. Once you have completed a part, you do not need to submit it again. Your score will be the combination of all of the parts

Note There may be more than 1 way to translate to C and arrive at the same assembly. The C is not the goal of the assignment. The goal is to write C code that will produce the same assembly when it is assembled, so either of the ways that we have found are acceptable.

Assembling the Code

To make sure you are assembling your code correctly, this is the line we are using to assemble all of the files for all of these assignments

gcc -mno-red-zone -fno-asynchronous-unwind-tables -S -O0 file.c

where file.c is the name of whatever C file you are using.

Makefile

There is also a Makefile uploaded here that you can use if you wish. To use this you will run it like this:

make FILE=file

where file is the name of the file you wish to assemble. Note You do NOT include the .c on the end of the file.

Submitting

You will submit your file, named as you wish, to Canvas for grading.

Grading

This is a multi-part homework. To be able to earn full credit you must do all of the parts.
